9airk0TorLFab_odIMqOgA.review_text: The food is sooo good.  The beg alecha is my personal favorite, and unlike many other Ethiopian restaurants, it isn't filled with bones and grisel.  I usually only order take out, because you get bigger portions! :)  One thing I don't really like is this place is slooooooooooow.  Even if you order take out, be prepared to wait.  I still give 5 stars though, because it's the best Ethiopian place in town.

Hq2TWfWXX18JODZj3P1JzQ.review_text: What a diamond in the rough - from the outside, you'd never expect what you find inside. It looks like a casual live music joint that might serve New American in a semi-sketchy area of town... when in fact you'll find an unusually great combination of Ethiopian food and live jazz.   The decor inside is actually quite nice with art pieces and comfortable seating; there are high tables for pairs that give you a good view of the musicians. Cocktails were delicious, many of which were  prepared with Abyssinian bitters.   Service was charming; got some great recs from our server. The spongey bread that came with the platters was the most delicious Ethiopian bread I've ever had!  Highly recommend:  - the vegetarian sampler patter - lamb platter (beg alecha) - spicy lentil sambussa - the abyssinian storm (Dark n Stormy with Abyssinian bitters)

LSxM1OEU38E72_W35hzDPw.review_text: This was the first time I've ever eaten Ethiopian food and I'll definitely eat it again after Sheba lounge! We were inspired by some hipsters who were totally full of themselves on BART. One of them said that they didn't like Ethiopian food because it was "just sponge bread and mush". We had to try it out of passive aggressive spite toward those college aged hippies who think that just because they've taken an art history class they are above you. I'm glad they did. The food was excellent.   We got the vegetable sampler (amazing), the spicy chicken (awesome) and the lamb, which was a little too gamey and had way too many bones in it. That was the only downfall of the food, everything else was great.  We chose to ate at a table instead of the easy chairs because we thought it would be easier to eat/talk at the table. But the restaurant is definitely not set up for this type of eating. The table was tiny and the chairs were uncomfortable. I would NOT want to be at this restaurant when it is packed! If it weren't for the shared plate of food we definitely wouldn't have had room on the table for our plates, we barely did with only two pates (one for food, one for bread).  The service was also a little lacking. Our water kept running out as did our bread. But the food was great, so I can't fault them there!

yZM8bO0dbhffVp6RCTFN5w.review_text: This is a rare Yelp "review in progress" since I enjoyed the food so much and want to explore more of the menu soon!  Ethiopian is one of those cuisines that is usually packed in restaurants that make Thai dives look fancy.  Sheba Lounge, however, has piano playing every night and boosts high quality and sometimes innovative menu items.  Finally a joint without florescent lighting!  Kitfo: I'm a huge steak tartare fan, but have been hesitant to try kitfo at lesser hole-in-the-walls that I wouldn't trust with raw meat.  Sanitary conditions seemed high here so I gave it a go and was not disappointed.  The meat is slightly warmed, but not cooked, which took me a while to get used but ended up liking.  The spices are what make it, so many and many unfamiliar, a great vacation from the French capers/shallots/parsley/cornichon presentation.  The soft injera offered a different texture from crostinis.  I'd almost say it would be too soft except for the chewy cheese curds offered on the side.  Red Sea: Basically a bloody mary with Ethiopian spices.  Usually I don't mention drinks, but had to in this case.  I mean, how many bars spice your cocktails with Ethiopian ingredients?  Added a great complexity and hotness.

P3gYzJ2UxK5mQlcRhQTq3A.review_text: The food, like most other Ethiopian restaurants, was yummy; however, being a ritzier restaurant, especially in SF, this restaurant seemed a bit pricier than most Ethiopian restaurants and the quantity appeared to be a bit less as well.  In addition, I was hoping for an actual piano lounge with someone playing the piano (and getting more of the lounge vibe), but this literally was a restaurant with a piano and music playing from the ceiling speakers, not the piano/ no live music on this particular night.   Initially, we ordered a margarita, a veggie combo, and then we ordered an additional red lentil because it was our favorite entree.  While the spinach, the yellow lentil, and the potato stews were good, they were not as flavorful as the red lentil.  The margarita was a bit too sweet for me, probably because it had an additional fruit flavor that they added.  They quite a bit, so that was nice (it was more than enough for my fiancé and I to split).  Though this was a piano lounge and there was a piano, no one was playing it and the music was not quite what I expected. We did go on Christmas Eve so maybe that was why, but it would have been nice to have had some live music.  The music playing was chill, which was good.  The ambiance was pretty cute, but nothing extraordinary.  Overall, it was good for an Ethiopian restaurant, but there are many more options in SF that I would try since I know I can get even more delicious Ethiopian food (at a cheaper price) elsewhere.

0bQIbFSdy0Rcdj5-Le4C9Q.review_text: Just like being in your own living room.  If your living room had a full bar, attentive bartender, and hot babes sprawled on your sofa in front of a roaring fireplace.

8ZWYZwYjO9vrfmdhDLc4TA.review_text: Of course being on Fillmore a restaurant will be chic and musically inclined, and we throughly enjoyed the late night jazz combo on a random weeknight.  However, what some people should know is that you can get relatively late night Ethiopian food here.  Most other shops close around 10pm but you can order all the way up until closing here.  Also, while some people may say this isn't as authentic as other restaurants, it is mild enough to introduced new people to this type of cuisine.  That is important to consider.  Strictly in terms of their food, it's an okay place.  Combine it with the ambiance and reasonable prices, it's a pretty good place.  It wouldn't be our first choice for Ethiopian, but if it's late, this will be our go-to spot.

2FaXRQT44HLMDxXrM9XVQg.review_text: This place confuses me. It's not really a lounge. The couches are usually reserved so there isn't much space to just come, sit, and have drinks.  But the servers are really attentive, they know the menu well and can make recommendations.

VAxxDTYktnUFKDjEF5L2jA.review_text: This review is totally mixed because the food was very good. But, the service was so horrible that it left  a bad taste in my mouth by the time that I left. Another thing that really pissed me off was I ordered a coke and it was $4. Then it came in a small rocks glass....$4 for a 10 ounce glass. Then when I got the bill they charged me for each one(they took it off when I complained to them). The service was so bad I would not even know where to begin to start. And by the time I stopped writing it would be like 3 pages and I would end up pissing myself off again by the time I was done. But, other then all of that.........The food was four stars. The piano was very nice to listen to!

hIGi8dLHqQNIb1Jyta3TUg.review_text: This place was amazing. My first time trying Ethiopian food and I loved it! You have to try the lamb dish. It was buttery and divine. Best thing on the menu in my opinion. The lentil dish from the veggie platter was also amazing. I would definitely go here again!   Take note, the interior is chic and much more classy than the outside of the restaurant would lead you to believe. The service was kind and receptive. I was in a large group with lots of different interest amd the staff helped us with the menu. They served us well. Overall, definitely worth 5 stars.

oCWpjKFufdeah57sF4coYw.review_text: Came here with some friends of ours for the lounge music on a Sunday...at 6:30 pm. music doesn't start till around 9...duh, what were we thinking?  Anyhoo, we almost bailed to go somewhere else (but really, who has lounge music going on when it's still daylight anyways?) but decided to give ita try since the lil missus and I had never had Ethiopian food.  Boy am I glad we stayed. The food was awesome. My wife ordere the Kitfo, (beef tartar) which I thought was really good. she thought it was a bit salty, but between four of us, there was nothing left. I ordered the Beg Alecha (lamb), which had a nice little kick and was super tasty.  Our friends ordered the Yasa-Tibs (catfish), and the special which was sea bass I believe, and both were excellent.  One of the real treats was...get this....the house salad. They make a house dressing (secret recipe I was told) that is lightly tangy, vinegar based, and seriously awesome. If I could figure out all the flavors I'd totally try to make it.  But overall the restaraunt was a pleasant surprise, and I am now a fan of Ethiopian food. Oh, and be prepared to eat with your hands, pretty kool... :)

fr4hVKMNKRQiTJiUxGr2yw.review_text: The milieu of this place is AMAZING! I'm in LOVE with the live jazz music. The band, the singer was all just perfect!! Sexy, suave and classy!  Not too upbeat for a dinner, not too mellow so that it'd be awkwardly romantic for a friends night out, and definitely not to loud (even for such a small, cordial restaurant) so you could still carry a conversation.   There's a bar area, a lounge area, and a dinner area, and usually, those don't really mix, but Sheba puts it together PERFECTLY! Usually, when a restaurant attempts to combine the three, those at the bar would be standing around and getting in the way of those at the tables. And those at the tables think the the bar guys are being rude and obnoxious, etc. etc. BUT, I LOVED that even though I was at a table (which, btw, I STRONGLY suggest you make reservations for if you're going on a Fri/Sat night), I was still able to mix with the tables next to me, as if we're in a lounge! Customers at the tables there are in their "lounge/bar mode", so everyone's just DOWN to talk to you, buy you a drink, and/or create all sorts of mischief!   Unfortunately, I wasn't too happy with the food. Ethiopian food is just too spicy and strongly flavored for my taste. I swear they added curry spices to EVERYTHING. I like curry and I like spicy...but they just overdid it on the sodium. I wasn't full, but I FELT full, because my palate was on overload. I had the:  1.) Sirloin Meat Sambussa with Tangy dip: 3/5. This appetizer is like two eggrolls, Ethopian style. Again, the flavors were just too harsh... I think I'd be happier with Filipino-style  lumpia with sweat and sour sauce.   2.) Sauteed sea Bass: 2/5. The sea bass was SO THIN that most of it was just the breaded part. Didn't taste much of the fish as much as I tasted a salty, crispy, crust. Oh, and the salad that comes with it on the side just seemed like it was soaked in dressing so much that the greens turned dark and whimpy.  3.) Vegetarian Sampler: 3/5. This one is pretty cool, but not in terms of taste...it wins kudo points in the "ethnically unique" category. In this dish, the various vegetarian samples come out on top of "injera", which is a thin, spongy, sour-flat bread that looks and feels like a pancake. You get more injera rolled on another dish. You unroll the injera and literally grab (yeah, using your HANDS!) the sampler, re-roll it, and eat it like a burrito! That was fun!   I'm a fan...not for the food, but for the people! Even the owner (a very motherly Ethopian woman) was incredibly sweet. When we told her that we had a reservation (and we WERE over 30 min late!!), she didn't even CHECK what our names were. She just made the table HAPPEN, because happy customers are her priority.   Next time, I would definitely come just to lounge. The incredible jazz music will take care of the night itself.

ehCameIBK2g7dw5rRXpvzQ.review_text: Once again at a loss for a place to eat in my hood that's not Japanese or Korean or too fancy, I look to Yelp reviews and found this place a hop, skip, and a jump from my house.  Finally deciding on Ethiopian and finding out that Sawa has closed, we decide on Sheba Lounge. I wasn't sure what to expect as far as the piano lounge was concerned, but it was nothing to be worried about. The musicians were playing some very good jazz, and there was an assortment of folks enjoying music, drinks from the full bar, and food. The only thing I would caution folks on is that with amped sound and a piano, it was not very good for dinner conversation. We had to talk very loud to make ourselves heard. I would go even just to have a drink and enjoy some tunes.  We ordered lamb, chicken, and I think a veggie combo. It was all delicious and very reasonably priced. We wiped the the platter clean with our injera. Thank goodness the kitchen was still open!

2DR_EnvIW72VuQ7vh87teA.review_text: While the atmosphere is fantastic and worthy of five stars, the food is inedible unless you are someone who enjoys eating straight spoonfuls of salt. I mentioned to the staff that my food had too much salt and was told there was nothing that could be done for it since it is all premade. I will not be eating here again, as it is possibly the worst ethiopian food I have had, which is unfortunate since there is certainly potential if they were not so heavy with the salt. Even my salt-loving friends thought it inedible. Alas. One star.

jUmnspdMwA8d-8pMeacaMA.review_text: I really wanted to like this spot as I live nearby, but unfortunately that was NOT the case. The service is terrible. It took over half an hour to even be acknowledged and even longer to get a drink. The food was also a disappointment. I can get pita chips from Safeway for much cheaper. Don't bother. There are much better spots in the neighborhood.

Tkv23R_GbCLcsaHmin-T4w.review_text: I've had a bad experience with Ethiopian food previously but decided to give it a second shot.  I'm glad I did.  The food here is delicious and everything on the menu is wonderful.  We got the vegetarian dish and for someone who usually eats mostly meat, I have to say this was a wonderful surprise.  The Kitfo (steak tartare) was also delectable.  Great music and vibe, I would recommend this restaurant/lounge to anyone.  Will come back again.

Kqar0e5uAQ3lhMlyUioX2A.review_text: I really like this jazz lounge. Supposedly there is live music every night, but I was here before the music started. The atmosphere is really nice, dark, with a very classy jazzy feel to it. This place also serves Ethiopian food -- I didn't get a chance to try it, but I will next time! The bartender, Bob? Rob? [Eeeek!] was super friendly and helpful. Great service and great place to chillax.

xgjjidOXjncyCXQPBLEn-w.review_text: So lucky we were.  Showed up on a Saturday night without a reservation.  By some miracle, we got a seat.  The menu is small but perfect - a big menu just means they are trying to do too many things.  The injera was excellent and fresh as someone else mentioned.  Friendly staff, although not particularly at your beck and call, so you have to be a bit patient.  Food was excellent!  I'm still sampling the Ethiopian food in the bay area, but this place get the maximum rating possible in my book, as compared to the all the places I've tried.  Not to say that it is the top, it just didn't disappoint me at all.  We ordered the vegetarian mix, more of the lentils, tibs wat and [chicken] wat.  Had tiramisu and the chocolate "cake" for dessert. I'd like to go back and try the honey wine.  They have a full bar, which seemed peaceful enough to sit at if you have a chance to do that.  We didn't order any drinks at our table, sans the bottle of wine.  The tables are arranged to create an intimate atmosphere; I wasn't really aware of how big or small the entire restaurant actually is.  If you're looking for Ethiopian, this place is definitely recommended.

thY4tADfgZPJwySQmRkG9g.review_text: If there's ever a time to realize that being a stupid white person doesn't always have it's advantages, it's when you learn that rather than eating each item on your Ethiopian veggie combo plate individually your dumb ass could have mixed them together for about ten times the deliciousness. Now that's an argument for mixing if I ever heard one, and my dumb Euro ass proved what a whitey mic white pants it was. Fortunately our server at Sheba lounge informed me that the red lentils and the 'omg' green collard greens actually go great together. Soon I was also combining the two with some yellow lentils. Who would have thought!?  Sheba gets extra credit for debunking this tendency of mine. Surly my future Ethiopian eating experiences will never be the same, and I may also carry over this lesson onto my Indian dining experiences - I'll sagg up YOUR chicken tikka marsala bitch! The food, however, was a little dry and gave me heart burn (wait, what doesn't anymore?). The injera was also pretty dry, and was not spongy enough. My Mr. had not had Ethiopian food at some of my other spots, and I kinda wish he had. It is also far  more expensive than the other establishments I usually go to, BUT it's Ethiopian food AND more than anything apparently it's fighting racism. HOORAY!

meaFvA6e2GA0VfuqeWNyWQ.review_text: Ambience is lovely. Food is good. We ordered the sambusas. Nice and spicy. We also got the Beg Alecha . It had a nice flavour, but the meat was too little for the price. The injera was nice and tender. With tip it came to thirty dollars. Overall not bad!

jahh3kGhmHJj3UHsMIqsmw.review_text: It's late at night. you're still craving some soul-soothing music, a bit to eat and a cocktail. You've found your locale! their kitchen was closed when we got there but they still had some tidbits for us to munch on.  a glass of red wine, a few sips of lagavulin a couple of sips from my friends double vodka rocks. Ummm! the night was good.  The bartender was super friendly and we felt like like the locals that we can be when we are in the vicinity.

TNWQuWa3kLH2Llx10LW1Yw.review_text: came here on a whim late one friday evening for the first time ever.  it had been a long week, i was tired, but damn this place is cozy.  the music, the lighting, fireplace, big comfty chairs definitely relaxed me.  this isn't much of a review because i only had a drink here, but any place that serves my IPA in a jar knows the way to my heart.  will come back to try the food.  until then...

29Oh2VSrju1Qz3qVZ13UMw.review_text: Ethiopian is my favorite cuisine and I have eaten at dozens of ehtipian places all over the country. This is by far one of my favorites. The ambiance is very upscale and not typical of what I am used to at ethiopian restaurants and they have live music nightly but don't let that throw you off from thinking that the cuisine is not authentic. The veggie sampler is AMAZING, every dish has a ton of flavor and the injera is fresh. There are some "not traditional" ethiopian dishes on the menu but they are still very tasty. We got the sea bass and it just melts in your mouth. So so yummy! And the price is the best part! Even cheaper than many of the regular ethiopian places i have been to. Great deal, delicious food and wonderful entertainment!

DQ8pttJAGrr0bvOnb-aBzg.review_text: Love the drinks and my favorite the Sausage Sliders.  Man it's so damn good.

l9nzeBnFBiIwz5jmBSKRmw.review_text: I am giving Sheba four stars instead of five because I did not dine on their food yet. I did however show up at about 11:00 on a Friday night and was able to choose from a variety of seats in different rooms. The options are couches, dining tables, high top bar tables or seats at the bar. It was not very crowded at all. The music was really nice and not too loud. We were able to have engaging conversations while still enjoying the music. Lighting was appropriately dim. We all look better when the lights are low right?  I was there on a third date and would say it was the appropriate place to wind up the evening.

_UCml1upjGCVYONwQe9-Dw.review_text: We enjoyed a nice glass of honey wine here one Saturday night, enjoyed the lounge and live music.  it was lovely! tho a little $$.  Ethiopian food and live music? what could be better, can't wait to come back and try the food.  Seating is limited, but I don't think I would change it.  Could be a nice location for a party.  lovely fireplace and comfy over-sized chairs.

5ZXT4BQB-C1XjUpKmh7kaQ.review_text: So maybe I'm a little biased since I celebrated my birthday here last week, but I had an absolutely wonderful time.    I made reservations 4 days in advance, and they kept calling me to make sure I was still coming and still had the same number of people, so when we arrived on Friday night, they had an entire sectioned reserved for our group of 14.  The section was perfect since it was isolated from the rest of the tables, complete with couches, coffee tables, big windows covered in sheer drapes, and a nice fire going (which we soon had to turn off since it got too hot).    Friends were trickling in, so the servers and bartenders were very nice, taking drink orders, appetizer orders, and checking on us periodically.  I suppose the service was a bit slow when it came to our entrees, and had I been really hungry I might have been a little upset.  But I was enjoying the company too much to mind that my night out was lingering on.    In terms of the food itself, I found it all delicious.  The lentil dip and sambusa appetizers were fresh, hot, and scrumptious.  And although I'm still not a huge fan of the Ethiopian bread, I am a huge fan of eating with my hands and filling bread with meaty and veggie goodness.  We tried almost one of every entree it seems, and I thought all the sauces, meats, and veggies were well cooked.  The beef tartare had some moments of chewiness, so I may forgo getting that again.  The portion sizes were decent, so I imagine if I came back with fewer people I could get filled up quickly.    The main reason I chose Sheba was because of the promise of live jazz after 9 pm with no cover!  The band was so close to us and the music was great.  It began as nice background music to our conversation and by the time dessert rolled around we were singing along (quietly and tastefully of course).    I love live music, good food, and a charming ambiance so I'll definitely come back here.  Thanks for a fabulous birthday, Sheba!

cz76cbJvk-ZLVTofNff0XA.review_text: Strong, delicious drinks. Cozy piano bar with a roaring fireplace and comfy seating. Def. need to come back here for dinner sometime.

G5LXEaxhQMF_BVjNHkVr7g.review_text: Oh Sheba Sheba, this piano lounge is a trip. The area is somewhat sketch, but then again right near The Fillmore and Rassela's and Harput's. Add the impending opening of Yoshi's and all of a sudden you have your own jazz preservation district, with Boom Boom Room up the street.  The decor is friendly and seductive at the same time. It's a great place to unwind with a martini or glass of wine, and they have a piano player almost every night of the week. My advice, go on a slow night where you have more of the bar to yourself, find a table and take in whatever jazzy standards your piano man is jazzing the night away with.  Note: Like Rassela's, the cuisine is Ethiopian, a strangely compelling bedfellow to the loungey atmosphere.

mFNPp84tN0RIIEJ9uwGWiw.review_text: fun live music on a Saturday night. lots of regulars on the weekends. sometimes it is hard to get a seat. however, you can just enjoy the music with wine in hand. one of my favorite place to stop by and unwind.

JPmEINY29c9W9gwVPb0_PQ.review_text: The key here is to get a spot where you can view the band. Because of a large wall down the middle of the restaurant, this is actually quite challenging.   Sheba has a different live band playing every single night of the week.   I went on a Wednesday night, and thought it might be a quieter night, but it turned out this place was bumping. There was a huge table right by the band in the prime spot. I think they know the band because a few of them ended up going up and singing.   The musicians were great, but 2 out of the 3 singers were actually not that great. I could see this place being perfect with the right band, but I guess a Wednesday night means the they don't bring out the top talent.   The atmosphere is pretty classy, perfect for a date. I just grabbed drinks but the Ethiopian food looked so good at the table beside me, I almost ordered a second dinner!  I'll be back here again, but will have to try a weekend night next time.

eADo2odte-4nVOXeYv152w.review_text: This is my favorite place to go for all occasions...late night, happy hour, nice gathering with friends. My partner threw me a surprise graduation party here and it couldn't have been more perfect! Ever since we have thrown other special events here (birthday party, even baby shower!). Sheba has become our extended living room--that's how comfortable it is.   The staff is so friendly and personable. They have live music that makes for a very comfortable and inviting environment. The food is delicious! I am vegetarian and only have a taste for mildly spicy food which they not only accommodated for, but they already had it on the menu. The place is beautifully decorated and even has a fireplace, it makes for a very romantic evening with a special someone or even a special time with friends. I would highly recommend Sheba Lounge to anyone no matter what size the party is or the occasion, they have mastered it all. They have great happy hour specials too!   Can you tell I am in love with this place?

fjhiDNGbrSfzfDxWbWgimA.review_text: Located in an uneventful section of SF's West Addition, rests a quaint and classy night spot -- Sheba Piano Lounge.  There are many cultural gems in the Bay Area and this small lounge is certainly amongst the most unique of such options. Seven days a week, the Sheba Piano Lounge hosts nightly jam sessions of a variety of music styles -- primarily jazz. We saw an eclectic mix of musicians and music styles last Sunday evening.  As you lean back and snap your fingers to the smooth sounds, peruse the bar menu to sample some of the unique cocktails and Ethiopian Dishes.  I will definitely be back to the Sheba Piano Lounge during my next trip to the Bay. Such a unique and eclectic place for a boy from the boonies such as myself.

sTI36pLS61hbU6JMcMu4YQ.review_text: This place is the joint! They have a happy hour that starts late 10 till close on the weekdays and 11-close on the weekends. I mean good music and a Jameson and beer for $10 "SOLD". There are always good people hanging around the place is full of cozy seats, fireplace + the food is really spot on as well. A must if your looking for a late night drink in the Fillmore..

yLX834G0MjSu2BbptBUShA.review_text: This was polar opposite as to what I expected upon arrival, but I was pleasantly surprised. Mostly because the nice lady behind the counter kept a drink in my hand at all times. Secondly, because they didn't give my friend a sideways look when she brought her kid with her.   So delicious. Go.

5X0eSDja58EOYvs_CPXbfg.review_text: OOOOOOOHHHH...the food here is AMAZING!  Spicy, like burn your gums, spicy.  But, amazing!  I had to "suck it up" as they say in order to survive the spice.  I'm happy I did.  Our order is as follow:  Sirloin meat Sambussa with Tangy Sauce=VERY SPICY!!!!!!  However, I came out finishing two of those things and I felt like a trooper.  Even after drinking 2 large glasses of water:)  The owner told me it was spicy even for her and you got it, she's Ethiopian.  Gomen=fresh collard greens.  A bit spicy, but YUUUUUUMMY!    Doro Tibs=Boneless chicken pieces.  Normally a spicy plate, but she made it without the peppers.  Wow, this plate is EXCELLENT!  Excellent spicing and the chicken is very tender.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND this dish.  Really enjoyed the food and the owner answered all of our questions perfectly and her recommendations were right on.  They give you silverware, but no need to even bother using it.  You eat with your hands the entire time.  Our server was also the bartender, so service was poor.  To give him credit, he had the entire restaurant and bar to take care of.  Pianist was excellent and the restaurant is set up nicely.  Very small, but a nice atmosphere.  One con:  There are NO FREE refills on soda.  However, that won't deter me because I don't drink soda, it was my friend.  I'll definitely be back and I recommend this place if you want authentic, excellent Ethiopian food.

m1YPLRS5Lepqi_cWXEPXFw.review_text: Live music on Sunday nights. It's really good! The food is delicious. The ambiance is somewhat romantic. There is candlelight and a nice big fireplace with couches.

iAhHH-TXZ9zIE86q6mGwAQ.review_text: I went here with a friend for dinner, and i have to say that I really like this place not only for the atmosphere, but the food was very good (try the sampler platter), and the owner came to each table to check on diners personally. They have a piano player on some nights, and the low lighting and intimate bar are nice for a date or small private dinner. A very pleasurable dining experience.

qQa9J0fXA6E-3JSFNsF7TA.review_text: A nice little gem hidden in the heart of the Fillmore. From what I understand, the former co-owner of Rassela's now runs this place. Very upscale looking interior. A jazz band awaits once you enter the door. They have two very large seating areas next to each other which accommodated our VERY large birthday party rather well. One of them was outfitted with lounge chairs and sofas and once I settled into my fifth Jameson and ginger it became mucho comfy. It was a bit empty for a Friday night, meanwhile business was booming across the street at Rassela's which is a bad sign.

EmfOSvDGDHrXE-FCOC9Y2g.review_text: Great ambiance and decor, although not very authentic ethiopian.  The piano adds a nice touch although it is somewhat random for an ethopian restaurant to have a piano bar.  The food is good, not exceptional ethopian by any means (compared to the food I've had in NY).  I didn't much like the boneless chicken dish but the vegetarian options were good.  The cheesecake (which I still have no idea why I am ordered at an ethopian restaurant) tasted like it had been frozen with the crust kinda soggy.

xtZMctl7AQNspIL_SF3guA.review_text: Just got back from dinner here, and absolutely loved it. The atmosphere and decor was very relaxing, and you have several options depending on what you're in the mood for -- tables, some comfy looking couches, and the bar. The food itself was excellent (highly recommend the vegetarian sampler on the Ethiopian menu), and we thought that it was much fresher and healhier tasting than some of the other Ethiopian restaurants we've been to in town. All in all, good place for a date, to chill and have some drinks with friends, or just to get your fill of Ethiopian food. Excellent addition to the neighborhood!

Q6T_qAMidIemQlINLwDDeQ.review_text: Me and my friend randomly ended up in this place on a Wednesday night, very hungry, and were disappointed when the bartender told us that they weren't serving dinner anymore. But the lady chef sitting at the bar said 'I can still do Ethiopian for them if they like.' My eyes lit up and stomach started growling with excitement.  The ambience was nice -- cute couches by a fireplace, a piano in one corner, with live music even on a Wednesday night. The food was excellent. I've always liked Ethiopian food because there's plenty of variety for vegetarians. The vegetarian sambussa was spicy, as were the red lentils in the vegetarian platter. We didn't have space for dessert, otherwise I would have liked to try that as well.  I have to go back again.

RVKadMPQnfWj7CxyX_gaGQ.review_text: just when you think all the cool spots you stumble upon a place like Sheba Lounge...wonderful sampler platters.  plenty for veggies and meat-eaters alike.  and what a cozy, warm atmosphere.  staff was super attentive and friendly.  on sunday early evenings there's a FANTASTIC jazz/blues band!  definitely check this place out....a real find.

mQUoN1QcGI3AEpu5su1PHg.review_text: What a cool little spot this is.  We just happened to drop in one evening while waiting for a show over at Yoshi's and immediately fell in love with it.  The atmosphere is warm, cozy and inviting, the music is quite good (have been back a few times and have never been disappointed in it), the food is excellent and reasonably-priced, the drinks were very good and the service was wonderful.  The staff are extremely cordial and we were fortunate to meet one of the owners who was going around to the tables and checking on her patrons. That's the icing on the cake.  Very classy.  What a great find in the historical jazz district.  We love it.

dOHsZ88NUZFqFhtXwB6zyg.review_text: Nice, chill jazz lounge. A great place to chat n relax with good music as a backdrop. Goood tej (ethiopian honey wine). Food looked good, I'd want to come back for dinner sometime.

_H1VvAk65d2z-2-XuLHkmw.review_text: This was fancier Ethiopian restaurant, but I had a pleasant time eating here. We had a huge party, so we took up the entire table in the lounge area. Unfortunately, there wasn't a piano playing when we were there at 9pm.   We ordered a variety of food such as the vegetarian platter and several meat options. The injera was mild and did not have a strong sour flavor. The flavors for the food tasted fancier, but had the spice. The veggie platter was good. I was also surprised to try the cod dish since I have not seen fish at other Ethiopian places.   The one thing that I didn't like about the restaurant was that there was a form automatically set out on the table. It sucks the fun out of eating with your hands.

RxQZaTfbF3H6vB1GmN3BMQ.review_text: Even walking out of Sheba's to a smashed car window and some stolen stuff, my great impression of this place is still untarnished.   Honestly, if this place was just a bar/lounge/restaurant, I'd give it a 4. But the fact that it's also a jazz lounge makes it that much better.   Lega Tibs is really really friggin good, although a little different from how I've had it before (as with everything else in this place... presentation is so untraditional!).   They use mixed greens instead of romaine (i highly dislike romaine), which is awesome.   JUST GREAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This place is some of my favorite things in one spot!!! alcohol, music, ambiance, and ethiopian food!!!!!

Lp2ndqej3RiExWotvpd7BQ.review_text: A taxi driver told us about this place.  I think the evening we spent at Sheba Lounge might have been our best evening on our honeymoon.  Steve, the piano player, was so awesome and funny and friendly too.  The food was great, wine was awesome, service friendly and welcoming.  I'll go back for sure next time I'm in town.

oZ4zwTAR2C9kGUL2aCGccQ.review_text: Stopped in here last friday after the Yellow Jackets/Mike Stern concert. Nicely appointed low key, soft ligthing, piano being played softly. Most people at the bar were watching the olympics. I ordered a glass of Spanish wine for $8.50 and it was decent. Swung around the backside and pulled up a chair to take in the live piano. It ordered the pita plate with hummus. I arrived in ten minutes and the hummus was merely ok, nothing special , edible , not memorable. The pita  was cut into pieces and deep fried like potatoe chips. Smooth music, the piano player was smiling and talking gently with a smartly dressed gentleman.  Low key. Nice. Very reasonable prices.  Customer service: ok. Decor: nice and clean. Fireplace too :)

_xVqtBEIBS2nTffGl9UrUQ.review_text: I would really like to come back here and eat.  I have been here twice for drinks, and the service has been quite friendly!  My friend and I came in and didn't know what we wanted.  The bartender told us she had Kashmir ( a liqueur with vodka, cognac, and vanilla-I think) on special so we had that in some hot tea (it was freezing that night!)  It was very nice!  Then she brought us some cracker-pita-tortilla-type chips with some lentils and a creamy dip, compliments of the house!  After she made the drinks for us, she asked if they were strong enough, then left us some extra to add to our drinks "as needed".  I felt like I was at someones house!  It was great.  I am definitely coming back for dinner soon! I highly recommend it if you want to lounge on sofas or sit in big comfy chairs by the fire.  Nice ambiance.

t7g2fD48YrEpxK8K1LyIRw.review_text: What a great date spot the low lights, romantic Ethiopian food that is shared family style and eaten with hands with spicy and unique flavors & finally some fun mood music.  We shared the vegetarian platter which comes with:  spicy yellow lentils, 2 little salads, spicy potatoes, a sour/sweet cabbage mixture and kale greens   we added the doro tibs (chicken sauteed in a spices onions and hot peppers  and of course  all wrapped up in spongy, sour injera.   honey wine was very sweet and strong but something new and fun.   Overall service was attentive, music was fun, atmosphere was romantic, food was delicious and I had a blast!

K3P--wZgF-jiByLqxMqzIA.review_text: Do you want to have Ethiopian food at a classy restaurant? Go to Sheba. I organized my friend's bachelorette party and we had about 10 friends showing up for dinner. Since we were all women (duh!), I wasn't sure if everyone was going to order a separate dinner. I know that usually Ethiopian food is served as a communal meal but here you get your own plate (with unlimited injera, don't worry). We brought up this concern and they were very willing to accommodate us. We got to sit in the lounge instead of the dining room. When we got there, they had already set up the lounge area. First I wasn't sure if it would work and the minute I mentioned that, the server went and spoke to the owner who personally showed up to ask about my concern. She was willing to give us a table except all were already reserved for big parties. Since there was no choice in the matter, we decided to stay. It turned out to be a really good decision. We could get everyone around the table and since everyone shared the dishes, it was perfect. The food is excellent. Everyone loved it.  And of course, there is piano music playing right besides you. The place is so classy and I will definitely recommend it to anyone. And the food is not expensive either. Wonderful place. Do check it out.

G0UWI0XQpjYzz9dB4h-26Q.review_text: Awesome food (vegetarian daal, but not the bland version), great cocktails (the espresso one was a favorite of the table), and fantastic live music. The waitress was very sweet and friendly, and the whole place had a great, laid back, slow vibe.

kUeMRDlXAnqAugNzGLxV-w.review_text: Great food and good live music, but service is mediocre.  I have been there twice and both times the bartender was also waiting the tables.  They are very slow so enjoy the live music while you wait.

kdfikdNoK1khFYRGmLlQhw.review_text: Sheba's has been our favorite place ever since they started at Fillmore location back in 2005. This is definitely one of my comfort spots in town - love the owners, Net is one of the nicest people I know; love the interesting food, with a special place in my heart for their Ethiopian tartar; usually like the music. We often come there at night and if we are not too hungry we just sit and chill with some red wine and a cheese plate. I have brought many guests from Europe there, many of them being rather picky with their lounges, and everyone totally loved the place. If you order appetizers-  don't forget the meatballs, they are truly amazing.

DMwp6ZDmshHRPeQVrYGoqQ.review_text: As my first foray into Ethiopian food, Sheba Lounge most definitely delivered! And I can honestly say that I'm in love with Ethiopian food.   First, the Lounge itself is beautiful. While I waited for my gals for our monthly dinner (yes, I was the first to arrive!!), the friendly hostess/server explained some cocktails to me in the lounge area with big, comfy seats. I ordered a drink and waited happily for the gals to arrive.   We eventually decided to sit down at a table and had our pick of the place since we were the only ones there (about 7 on a Monday night; by the time we left it was starting to pick up). We ordered 3 servings of the vegetarian combo platter, and the server gave us more injera when it looked like we were getting low. EVERYTHING in the platter was delicious. One of the items was a little too spicy for me, but everything else was perfectly spiced and so yummy! We didn't order desert because, as my loyal readers know, I always have cupcakes.   My only complaint (and reason for the loss of 1 star) was that the music was a bit loud for us being the only ones in there. It wasn't the live music (that didn't start until after we left, but I'd love to hear it), but just the music playing over the speakers. Don't get me wrong, it was GREAT music, but I found it difficult to hear my friend sitting right next to me.   We will definitely be back here, but will also be trying the rest of the Ethiopian places in the city!

Q-mV092vG1JmLsUe4vpvDw.review_text: Wow. This place just oozes sexy.   Boyfriend and I went to Sheba Lounge to see our friend's band, London Street, perform. We were dazzled, put under a spell by the music and the lights and ambiance of the place. We sipped on a bottle of their Syrah (wine special), some Lagunitas, and ordered the spicy lentil sambussa (the best part!!!), vegetarian sampler, and cheesecake brownies for dessert. My tastebuds went to heaven and are still lingering there.   It was my first time trying Ethiopian food. As of then, I'm addicted. Cannot wait to go back. Fortunately for us, London Street performs there at least once a month.   Thanks to Sheba Lounge, we had a super fun romantic date night. This is a great place to charm a special someone. The couples at Sheba looked so classy and beautiful.

dQ8gu3NUmp1gn_L8kHJyfw.review_text: Went on a Wednesday evening, the place was moderately busy.  Ambiance was nice, food was excellent and the service was exceptional.    The piano player was not there, but everything else made up for that.  I'll just have to go again.   It's a nice spot to take your sweetie on a romantic date, just make sure the piano player will be there for that added touch of romance.

cXv1g6SGYqNkrfqiCI1Zxw.review_text: I fought an urge to hug the two women who run this place.    First, they comforted me with delicious Ethiopian food on a massive combo plate (lentils, chicken, lamb, beef, collards, chickpeas, cabbage).   Second, they were visibly happy that we devoured our massive combo plate.   And they smiled. A lot.  Why did I want to cross town to eat here again the very next day?  Because I felt fed rather than served.   My friend made a great comment about the duo's mothering instincts, which I've forgotten, probably because I washed my meal down with some chilled Tej.    The lamb is a developing-world version: bone in and strong.  We thought the beef was tops, but the chickpeas, collards and lentils were close contenders.

iZeT4iDRLtlARLoX3R-q0g.review_text: Awesome food!  Great live music.  Service was a bit slow, but we were in good company so it was forgivable.

Ct456aEICzDfn03MHZCzsw.review_text: Recently opened alternative to Rassella's, near O'Farrell, but believe owned by same Ethiopian group. Pomegranite sauce chicken. Haven't tried the samosas yet, but just for a change of venue and scenery it's worth it to break the place in before going to The Fillmore. Wild metallic purple, orange, red curtains. Have to mention the RED SEA...metamet (Ethiopian) spice in a semi-bloody Mary...$8 +$1.60 to $2 depending on spiciness! It cleared my sinus right quick. Whiskies, cocktails...with a name like "Ex-boyfriend" gotta think of that creative dudette.  Thought I saw a flyer that said they now have happy hour Mon-Fri 5pm-7pm...proally no piano tinkling then.

LXW5nBtiHs76Z4NHiwHduQ.review_text: Run by a sweet middle-aged woman from Ethiopia.  Very warm with Jazz at a level you can enjoy and talk to your date.  The food is interesting, sometimes eating, (always with your right hand only) from a thin chewy dough under the food you wrap the light flexible crust abound meat, like a soft taco and eat.  I love the place, the bartender will remember you and always has a smile on his face.  The place has warm fire places and tables to talk to your dining companion around a small, but friendly.  I went to a Jazz bar in Pleasanton and they played so loud, you can't even hear any conversation, which is why I love Sheba.

vBvX7fTkZuKveg9AOLL8Hg.review_text: oh, baby. I can't wait to come back again. I went to celebrate a friendsie's early b-day and went here for dinndinn. I honestly didn't come here with high expectations with the food. I read the other reviews on yelp which said the food was okay, but the music was awesome, so I didn't expect much of the food. I also didn't know what ethiopian food was or how spicy it would be.   I'm not normally boring, but I stuck with some sliders. They were probably way fattening, because I had two and I was full (they give ya three) but I also got  the baklava as well. It's a dark room, with fake candles (so sad), but the ambiance was romantic and classy and jazzy and chic.   I was worried I'd have to dress up (worry is the wrong word, I love to dress up! I love putting on the fancy make up and the heels and the skirt/dress) but since dressing up would mean high heels, a short skirt and trying to find a super warm jacket, I decided I would take my chances and dress down in jeans and normal attire (with heels, can't forget that). I was pleased that some people dressed up in sheba's lounge, but a lot of people kept it casual, so I didn't feel outta place.   The jazz started at 9pm, so don't expect to have a deep convo after nine... and it was pretty much great!! Sheba, or the lady who owns the place greeted everyone personally and asked about the food and stuff and my friend got a free cheesecake whoothoo! free stuff!  Oh, and the sliders were as uhm-azing as the jazz performers (forgot their names, but they were sellin their cd's) and honestly, I ordered sliders, because I thought, "I can't go wrong with burgers," and I was so right. I didn't go wrong with them, but they were the best little things I ever ate! I was screaming at my friends to try a bite.. I probably shouldn't have done that, because it would mean less for me... but when I love something, I would want my loved ones to partake in that delish something as well!  on a sidenote: the 22 is right outside Sheba's which takes you the to Church and Market M-line, and after dinner, my friendzies and I waited for like.....alongtime and then decided it wouldn't  be coming and went looking for the 38... it mine heels... and we saw two 22 buses broken down.WHATARETHECHANCESTHATBOTH22'SAREDOWN  houston, we got a problem.  BUT THAT IS A TANGENT. back to sheba's lounge: So it was pretty unanimous, out of the four things my four things ordered, it was pretty much agreed that we would definitely come back again and that sheba's piano lounge was such a hit!

daEKn0SlW3j3-8zAXx3xBA.review_text: The atmosphere is very lounge, dark and sexy. The lentils had an enjoyable heat to them. The spicy meatballs were pleasantly spicy and addictive. The chicken was very moist.  Service was friendly and very accommodating. Perfect for large groups plus a great neighborhood spot.

2JeI_lY2OyPM-kfa4yZufw.review_text: Finally, I can write a review for my opulently atmospheric Sheba Piano Lounge. My gf and I came here after having diner at Basil Thai Restaurant and Bar in the SOMA for some cocktails.   The real reason we came was because of the lovely live jazz music and romantic atmosphere by the fireplace. Also, we had about an hour to kill before our movie started at the Kabuki Cinema down the block.   I must say, I wouldn't mind dining here next time because the selection of food, with the pairing of cocktails and wine seems very tempting. It isn't your usual fare, definitely not.

qo_YuHJXHemYQbg5ZIAqoQ.review_text: I've been here only once but definitely planning on coming back. It's a great restaurant with a really intimate ambiance. We ate in the lounge area and were only a few feet away from the performers. We had cocktails (very good) and split some appetizers. The food and drinks were all outstanding. Plus, it was fun listening to the live music. Already looking forward to a second visit.

OMoBzr4FhDkk7yV8zYtmiw.review_text: When I go out with my group of boys we typically sample the majority of the menu.   We feast, we drink, we are merry.  Fried is always good and the Mushroom Sambussa and the Crab Sambussa were delicious filled pastries.  These were also a good way to ease my friends into this cuisine they were new to.  The Vegetarian Sampler was a chance to check out a large selection of the menu.  The Gomen claimed the win though.  The collard greens sautéed in Ethiopian spices were a hit with everyone at the table.    The Lega Wat grabbed our attention immediately after being handed the menus.  The sirloin tips marinated in white wine and sautéed with rosemary, onions and jalapenos actually tasted as good as it sounded.  After sampling the cocktail list, two particular drinks were ordered multiple times: Selassie (Jim Beam, Pernod, and house made bitters). I had heard tales of their bitters but not being a fan I had reservations.  These aren't your everyday bitters though, yum!  Makeda Martini (Hendricks, cucumber, white grape juice, orange liqueur).  This one essentially tasted like a spa treatment.  There were two things that weren't quite up to par but I'm not going to hold it against them.  Their Kitfo (steak tartar)  wasn't exactly a quality cut. I'll hand it to them though, they weren't shy when it came to piling up the raw beef.  The entertainment was also a slight disappointment as the band was more jazz than Latin. We were hoping to be doing the samba to work off the extensive meal.    Overall, we had a great time and plan on returning.  Ethiopian food is awesome for groups so adding music to the mix only makes the evening better.

47xP83UsyZq6ErmA98OvAg.review_text: When my husband suggested we try Sheba I was skeptical. Jazz piano and Ethiopian?? The moment you walk in you don't care what kind of food is being served. The atmosphere is warm and homey but sexy, like if you were in an international version of a Pottery Barn living space. We wanted to try the honey wine but they were out. Instead we had a wonderfully refreshing Riesling. The spicy lentil sambussa was fabulous, but make sure you have some water handy. The beef sambussa was divine; tender and wonderfully flavored. I got the Doro Tibs which was  nicely flavored and not at all spicy. Oh, and the jazz piano was great. The performer's voice was smooth and sultry, like you were with one of the great jazz ladies from the 1920s. Would definitely come here again.

znNbE3qZxOqZhQZP8jYclQ.review_text: Yum Ethiopian!! Strange to go to japan town and strange that it's a jazz piano bar but whatever. I'll do anything to get Ethiopian when I can (oh Honolulu when will u catch up?). Service was slow at first but then got better - I guess we came in pretty early like 6. But they were quite friendly. The pianist started around 7 and mostly played classical and that was strange. Food was delicious although a but on the fiery side. Fingers sticky and stinky and wonderful as always after Ethiopian.

HSiz-rO_OsdKx7NWXqTihw.review_text: I went on a Friday night to hear some good jazz and have a few drinks. RIght away, I loved the vibe. The lighting is dim, but too dim. The decor is good and there is plenty of seating, including some soft chairs and couches.  The drinks seemed over-priced to me ($8 makers+coke).  The band playing was pretty mediocre, so, if you're going more for the music than the hang, I'd try a night other than Friday.  I would still go back sometime.

VFxrLIlgApHIdOCrkAYIGA.review_text: Found this place last saturday after seeing a movie at Kabuki theater. Laid back bar with room to breathe and wandering "bartenders". I didn't have any food here but I think it's their main focus as the bar was poorly staffed that night.

Jdr_siMLJVEtXcGM0NIIXQ.review_text: This place plays awesome music! The waitress was incredibly knowledgeable about the menu. The food was to die for! Great atmosphere.

klLZFhfRHOaRb0EQphgD9A.review_text: went here just last night, so everything is still in my mind! (i should really start writing these reviews more quickly)  The location is alright (western addition) but it was so difficult to get parking here last night as they had some live music playing right outside Sheba.   So, i have been wanting to try Ethiopian for a long time, but the idea of food sharing (from same plate) doesn't exactly appeal to me, so kept postponing! IDIOT!!  The food was so good! the ambiance itself was OK (too dark) and the music is too loud, and its so crowded so too warm (almost hot) in there.  We tried the lentil sambusa, the beet salad, the vegetarian sampler (the dark lentils was OFF DA HOOK!), the doro tibs, the doro wat (both chicken dishes). the latter was an Indian-esque curry with garlic, ginger, tomato and onions with chicken and boiled egg. Next time i am definitely going to get that (minus the chicken to appeal to my vegetarian preferences).   the service was real slow, but we were there with friends and were in no particular hurry, but even she admitted that she was a bit sparse in appearances.  My friend tried to an Ethiopian wine (honey wine or something) and it was really good! i got a pinot noir, but it wasn't too great (i mean i drank every drop, lol).  Haven't tried any other Ethiopian joints, so dont know this compares but 3/4 of us have been and they all agreed this place was really good. So definitely give it a try!

aFO_yCma7PImpdPkA8ZC-A.review_text: First time trying Ethiopian food. Suffice it to say, it will certainly not be my last.  Atmosphere was nice and the live jazz/swing music was appreciated (it is on Fillmore afterall). The food, however, was much better than anything I had expected and, honestly, I didn't really know what to expect.  The wifey and I ordered the vegetarian sampler and the beg alecha (braised lamb in Ethiopian herb sauce). Our orders also came along with a full plate of injera (thin Ethiopian spongy flatbread that has a similar taste to sourdough). I was very delightfuly surprised by all of the flavors; everything was delicious. Any vegetarian and non-vegetarian alike would especially love the sampler.  We also tried a glass of Ethiopian honey wine at the end of our meal which was quite sweet; having a very notable yet unique honey aroma and flavor.  Chill spot. Delicious food. Cool vibe. Live music. Yeah...this is my jam.

pBNqvV5IkldL24s418ZzRw.review_text: Very cute, cozy and comfortable.  The food was good-  but i have nothing to compare to as it was my first experience!  I love the mix of comfortable jazz and good food, the music got a little loud at times, but maybe i was just tired that day.  They need more wine and sparkling wine options by the glass. I dont want a whole bottle but i also dont want that bottom shelf wine ur serving by the glass. =/ I think ill stick with beer next time.  I've also been here once when i wasnt eating - and the lounge area is great for just chillin and listening to some good beats!

XkLK2iBsgqF6mWwDfRgqqQ.review_text: stopped in for a drink before dinner last night.  when my friend described the place as an ethiopian piano bar, how could i say no?  i have decided he has good taste.  there were mostly jazz type folks a generation or more ahead of me.  you know, fedora type hats, cool cats.  the piano man was good.  i didn't try any of the food but my pomegranate martini was pretty tight and tasty.  i like rassela's and arang up the street so i could see myself here again.

63SQPROZ48xwGUb2LloFQA.review_text: My buddy took me to Sheba for my birthday the other night, and it was awesome.  He'd never had Ethiopian and he's a nut for new experiences, so it seemed like a natural fit. I, on the other hand, have always loved all things Ethiopian, and some times have a tough time getting anyone else excited for it.  The set up of the restaurant is intriguing and we sat at a couple of those lounge-ish chairs in the front of the place. Really comfortable. We ordered the normal shared type plate and it was delicious. To we had lentil sambusa, which is the kind of thing I'd like to learn how to make at home.  My only knock on the place is no Ethiopian beer...what's up with that?

G1QCbj-a_vciRvCyqZlgCw.review_text: I have had Ethiopian food before and I thought I just did not have the right taste buds for the food from this part of the world. Boy was I wrong! The food here was delicious, fulfilling and from what I presume authentic. My best fried hosted her birthday dinner here and from the sensual jazz music to the accommodation for our party, the service here is great!  Food= Delicious Service=Awesome Parking= Did not drive that night so no qualms on my end Environment= Modern, clean and has an old fashioned quaint feel  THANKS SHEBA

swn4FL2qDyBtby7lZfR1UQ.review_text: This place has become my after-work-hang-out.  They always have live music and their happy hour food is great.  We love Derek!!!  He is an amazing bartender.

LzfpQ9PbbeWW8gWIZc6eqQ.review_text: 5 star service 5 star environment  3 star food  Kitchen  was closed (the hours listed are for the bar) but they were nice and offered us a limited menu. The waiter was super nice and very helpful.  The place is nice, live jazz, low lighting...  The food could be better. The vegie mix had realy tasty salad, the rest of the entries -- not so good. The chicken curry was not so ethnic.  Portions are smaller than most Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants.

1ABe3UOXXWTNR0YXix5Fsg.review_text: Love the place..great ambience! Cozy! Blues was marvelous....must visit.

KURUGmYN2kwDpr6BcEcrRA.review_text: 3.5 stars! This place is kinda cool! Its an Ethiopian jazz restaurant! The food was good, and drinks were strong. Its dark...and the music is really loud. A bit hard to chat with other people...and the owner watches things in the restaurant like a hawk! I kinda snuck in some leftover korean food, and wanted to eat some along with the entrees we ordered...she caught us and told us to put the outside food away. OOPS.

3c705xYacUdsFuHx1rxzwA.review_text: I looooovvvvved this place.  J'adore Ethiopian food, and my standard is quite high. I don't like just any Ethiopian restaurants.  Just like anything.. if the decor(or the looks, the appearance) of a restaurant(or a person) is nice and fancy, one gets to be skeptical of the food(the personality) .   But, this place. I loved not only the outside (the decor and the atmosphere) but also the inside (the food).   Food was spicy and fierce in that exciting way. We had the lamb tibs and veggie combo. All the veggie was excellent. Lamb tibs was a teensy bit on the watery side, but I say it was still great. The Injera(the bread) could be more moist, spongy, and sour.I want to be there right now and finish off whatever they have left for tonight.. but I should go to sleep for work tomorrow. This place is not afraid to use spice and I love that boldness about this place. Other places.. I could sense that other places were holding back on the spice.   Oh, also, the people there are super friendly.. and I'll be a regular soon enough to know all their names. Ah.. i love this eating life.

s_bwB79YSbfJWcqXCUTqBw.review_text: excellent alternative when you get tired of more traditional eritrean/ethiopian food such as assab/massawa.  the whole piano bar setup is also pretty entertaining.  and the full-bar aspect differentiates it from the others.  there is also Club Waziema which is also hilarious as its an ethiopian food irish pub.

ABedbkKIgR8PjKl5sP9nyg.review_text: This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and I was pleasantly surprised. It was cozy, the service was great and the food was yummy -though a little pricy - all served on the injera bread. My friend and I weren't super hungry so we ordered a sampler type plate to share it was plenty.    The music was good though it was LOUD. We could hardly hear each other which is why I give it 3 stars.  If you want to go here for a catch up with a friend or just to talk, its difficult to do when there is a band. Though, maybe we were just sitting in the wrong spot?

yZbDsPetl-ePLTxywjU58A.review_text: a small quiet, romantic with piano lounge...love that !!!food is exotic...

BbG-saP_hHFS62OQMIBNsA.review_text: One of my favorite neighborhood spots.   Live music every night and a great late night happy hour. The best is when you can snag a spot on the couch by the fireplace and  relax with a drink, a bite, friends, and great music. It's getting a little too well known...good for business, but bad for those of us who used to have it all to ourselves!

mR65qkdd6uiOQEPwSMhgGw.review_text: I had reserved a table for 20 people for my birthday last year. They did accept the reservation, though honestly they aren't equipped to host a party of 20. They called me that morning asking me to preorder stuff. Since I didn't know what others in my party would like to eat, I pre-ordered 5 vegetarian samplers.   Guess what, they ran out of food, silverware, and glasses. They got embarrassed and then got the food from a neighboring Eithiopian restaurant (that's what they told us) and then served us with disposable silverware and plastic water cups.  Good food and great music and ambience. I just wish they were honest enough to not take the reservation for 20, for which they obviously aren't fully equipped.

IJABCqLsGgT8DxqujUQmiA.review_text: Hidden gem in the Fillmore District! We saw Sheba open up and were happy to see a new place in the District. The menu just recently expanded - full Ethiopian dinner now, along with a Lounge menu. The drinks are great but pricey. Food prices are great. Staff have always been wonderful, though the service can be a little slow at times. Hope they are successful and stay around!

2oD-vur-aVCsOVdW0iUevw.review_text: Great lighting in a romantic and relaxed atmosphere with an excellent location (across from Yoshi's and convenient street parking is easy if one arrives around 8 or earlier).  Tip of the Top Blues band playing at 9:30 on a recent Saturday was excellent - great vocalist, wonderful song selection, ideal volume and good vibes. Everyone appeared to be having a great time and enjoying chatting with their dinner mates while still enjoying the live music.   The pomegranate meatballs were yummy, the veggie sampler provided a good variety and the baklava was tasty (though it would have been much better if they had decaf coffee to serve with it - only regular coffee here, to my dining partner's disappointment). We'll be back (but will skip dessert if they don't have a decaf coffee or tea selection in the future). It would also be a huge improvement if they removed one of the 2 top tables from each row in the main dining hallway since we were all packed in there and had to hear the conversations of the ajoining tables since they were 6 inches away and had to wiggle the tables together for those on the bench side to get out.  That's it, fewer tables and decaf drink offerings and it's 5 star worthy!

lFpEKQtS6NjvJqy-7Rujug.review_text: It's really a shame that cities--especially ones like SF--don't have more places like Sheba. I love my funky, noisy watering holes, but it's also nice to hold court in a chill spot like the Sheba Lounge.  This is a real deal piano lounge--not a modern-style upscale lounge with electronic music, expensive and trendy drinks (and patrons), etc.  My man on the piano (Ricardo Scales) is truly a refreshing person. This isn't the bitter and jaded "Piano Man" that Billy Joel sang about. This cat loves his music and has no problem talking with you about as he improvises on riffs, both original and familiar (his version of "The Look of Love" made my night!).  And as usual, don't listen to the "the area is sketchy" jive (what do people require of this city to feel safe and comfortable? Should we turn it into one huge Marina/Union Street/Mini-Mall scene? But I digress).  This is very nice, renovated, well-lit slice of Fillmore Street. Even on a pretty quiet night at 1 a.m., I was able to snag a taxi within minutes of leaving.

mLw4kUjqF8ddBPBhJhnPRw.review_text: The best Ethiopian restaurant in the city, I just wish this place had a larger menu. Love the kitfo prepared "lub-lub," the gomen, and everything else for that matter.

JzDPb9rFVNHsMWqaCGWjHQ.review_text: I don't know what to make of Sheba, other than I am fascinated with their concept and think it has a lot going for it.  For example, it's an Ethiopian restaurant with a live jazz band. A live jazz band! Ok, it's maybe not always jazz (sometimes it's a guy singing standards with piano accompaniments) but let's not pick nits here -- this is a fantastic idea! Who came up with this? I'd like to buy them a drink.  There's lots of seating and a fireplace* next to comfy leather couches. Not fantastic for large groups but if you're six-to-eight people, you should be able to find a home here.  On the other hand, that was hands-down the worst Old Fashioned I've ever had. I mean, there was a lemon wedge in it. A lemon wedge? Yes, a lemon wedge. I could get over the fact that it was really small but my girlfriend's cosmo was red dye and vodka. Which, y'know, great for getting hammered quickly but not so much on the taste department.  On the other, other hand** the service wasn't necessarily "bad" as it was completely mixed up. Bartender comes up to take our orders, yet we have no menus, so we pick our go-to drinks. She leaves and the waitress comes by to drop off menus. Confused, our soon-to-be-but-we-didn't-know-them-yet friends sitting next to us explain that's sort of how it works when you're just getting drinks and to sit back and relax.  So, we do as instructed and then the waitress comes back to take our order a few minutes later, only to be informed we'd given it to the first woman who had come by. The waitress seems confused by this, but takes the menus and leaves.  Ten minutes later we get our drinks.  There's a lot to like about the possibility at Sheba but they're going to have to work on the service and the drinks to make it a go-to place. Which I'd like to do because Ethiopian Jazz!  * - Trufax: you can use a fireplace year-round in San Francisco. They don't put that on the brochures, though they should.  ** - Going all Zaphod Beeblebrox up in here.

4oJUXOQPQ_G52VkJyf3oOQ.review_text: Tried Sheba a couple nights ago for the first time.  Ordered the starter of Steak Sambusa, then Vegetarian Sampler and Doro Wat. The veg sampler was great in variety - with the collard greens, chickpeas, salad and more.  The Doro Wat was also delicious and this place does NOT skimp on chicken.  There was so much meat!  It was nice and tender, so easy to eat with injera.   One con was that the food took quite a while to arrive (about 25 min), and they weren't busy.  This looked like it was because there was only cook in the kitchen, so I don't really fault them because it was a Sunday night.  Even the sambusas were late, and interestingly looked like spring rolls but were tasty nonetheless.  They came with a semi spicy sauce that went well. Another con was the seating wasn't too private, but given this is a piano lounge I think the airy open feel is what they're going for. The seats were quite close together all around the restaurant, making for everyone's conversation public.   The staff was friendly, attentive and knowledgeable about the food.

zG5ukGhfJZ98VvSUkQgGkg.review_text: This is a unique little place on Fillmore - I've been here twice now, and I'm sold. It was after shows at Yoshi's, and both times it was the perfect after-show place to be. The first time was on a Friday night, and while walking by I caught the sound of a smooth, sweet voice drifting out onto the sidewalk, accompanied by a jazz piano. I went inside, was greeted by a very friendly woman (I think the owner) and sat down for an Ethiopian dish, a glass of wine, and wonderful entertainment, all for less than $20. I loved the performer, who was advertised as being there on Friday nights, (although I didn't see his name posted for this Friday). Although my dish was a little spicy for me, and I found that it helped to wrap it in the Ethiopian bread. I'll admit that it was the music, not the food, that attracted me, but I want to try more dishes.  Tonight after a show at Yoshi's, I was there again, and this time it was intentional. I fell into one of the several empty arm chairs, relaxed in front of the cozy fire, ordered the $4 chocolate cake (delightfully good, filled with chocolate chips), and sat back to enjoy the music that was playing overhead. It was mesmerizing, and I could have stayed there for hours it it wasn't for work tomorrow. I paid my $4.34 bill feeling I had gotten so much more out of my visit. Great service, amazing ambiance, friendly staff, and food you don't find everywhere else.

CBwPegIptHW0vwGsaxcfHQ.review_text: Great place!  Came here based on some recommendations I received after posting a question on here (thanks everyone who responded).   We went on a Sunday night and the place was pretty dead & quiet.  Which was nice.   And finding parking close by helped my good mood even more.  The food here was excellent.   We got the Vegetarian sample plate along with two main dishes (lamb and beef).  The beef was awesome, lamb was ok.  Will definitely order the sample & beef next time.   Great bar too, nice and stiff drinks.  With food and drinks, and tip, my bill for two was 100 bucks... so not too shabby.  This was also one of the few lounges I've been to that actually felt like the way a lounge should be.  Nice, chill vibe... great tunes being played on the stereo... dim lighting.    Highly recommended!  Especially if you need a place to eat if you are going to a show at the Fillmore.

d1VXeXMq67_QgdvWY1tcKQ.review_text: The purpose of this place was to provide a less-crowded, laid-back alternative to Rassela's. In that regard, it's certainly succeeded.  But unlike Rassela's, the portions here are extremely small. While the food is good, a bunch of us went and ordered a few appetizers to split, but we barely got any food. Drinks were pretty good though, piano player was all right.  Also, the happy hour is not on all days.

UD1ENQnxnx5vfAQX6hg_sQ.review_text: The adventures of the Hamburglar continues.    The Hamburglar was feeling spontaneous and wanted to divert his burger adventures for something different, something ethnic, something Ethiopian?  We were eager to return to Sheba, this time for dinner.  We arrived early and started with cocktails:  Selassie, a concoction of Jim Bean, Pernod & house made Ethiopian bitters; and Solomon's Julep, a blend of Jim Bean, fresh mint, sugar and soda.  Absolutely refreshing.    For dinner we selected the Gomen (fresh collard greens sauteed with fine onions, garlic, oregano, ginger, tomatoes and Ethiopian spices); Mesir Wat (lentils cooked with chopped onions, garlic, ginger, olive oil and Berbere sauce); and Beg Alecha (tender pieces of lamb braised slowly in green pepper, flavored with Ethiopian herb sauce, ginger, rosemary and a touch of jalapeno pepper).  All this was served on Injera or Ethiopian bread, spongy in texture and more substantial than a crepe.  The Injera is used instead of utensils to pinch your food.  Amazing and unusual flavors abound.  A definite presence of heat that permeated our lips.  Simply wonderful!    The Hamburglar's first exposure with food from the Motherland.  No burger here, but an experience well worth searching off-the-beaten-path moments.

1dhMYD2pJ19vPvADcpJe7A.review_text: Truly what a good piano lounge should be. The ambiance is loungey and the atmosphere very intimate. The bar area is nice and the bartenders here are true mixologists. The food here also is definitely above par. Definitely a great date spot. Can't wait to come here again.

1Qmb5ubFUOmlVUf_RbdsRQ.review_text: Sheba is a class act. From the lure (live jazz) to the service to the last bite and sip, it is always a smooth, relaxed evening here. I especially enjoyed the latin jazz band  -- a 6 person band IIRC.

iiytiZKqlnwdE_9YjwIlGw.review_text: Sophisticated, comfortable atmosphere with couches, coffee tables, flowers. Full bar. Pleasant and accomodating staff. Live jazz in the background - not too loud for a conversation. Goat cheese appetizer is yummy, but everything is kind of expensive for the amount you get. Probably not great for kids, but good for dates and groups. Good lighting and clean bathroom.

LlzQJJbS_JxKVVBgnoncHg.review_text: Ethiopian and Jazz? yes you read right. The rather peculiar combination of these two concepts came together to form a truly fantastic experience. I LOVE jazz music, and not having much experience with Ethiopian food, I definitely came with an open mind. I must say that I was pleasantly surprised.  The place was dimly lit with candles placed on the table, creating a relaxing and inviting ambiance. The waitress was friendly and very helpful when we told her that it was our first visit. The jazz quartet started playing around 8:30pm, and began with some slow jazz.  We started off with two glasses of honey wine that I would definitely recommend. It was sweet and I could almost taste a hint of honey in the aftertaste. For dinner, we ordered the Spicy Lentil Sambussa, Lega Tibs (tender sirloin tips marinated in white wine) and Beg Alecha (lamb braised in Ethiopian sauce). The food comes with a plate of rolled up "Injera", which is the Ethiopian staple bread. We tore small pieces and used it to scoop the dishes. The food was delicious and the portions were just right. The bill came down to $60 with tips for two people.  Overall, I had a wonderful time. I definitely enjoyed the live jazz music and cozy setting. I also like the location of the place; not far from Yoshis and Japan town. Whether it is to catchup with friends at the bar, or for a romantic date, or just to try something out of the ordinary, this place serves as the perfect place.   Note: Due to the layout of the place, not every table has a direct view of the jazz band. If that is important to you, call in to request a table that allows for that.

IcJfiXkrYuu30aVxnY1Z0Q.review_text: The food was disappointingly forgettable, and the prices very dear at Sheba.

c8FOqDRhtL7q_YsQio6bog.review_text: This is one of my favorite (lesser known) bars on Fillmore Street.  Located in the Fillmore's Jazz District, Sheba Lounge is an intimate spot to take a date or catch up with a friend. The drinks and prices are decent. I like sitting on the couch by their inviting fireplace and listening to the piano player or house jazz band. I so much prefer the chill vibe to this place versus Yoshi's or other crowded venues in the hood. Unlike those other places, Sheba feels like a real neighborhood jazz bar.  FYI - the owners of Sheba Lounge also own Rassela's across the street. Like Rassela's, Sheba offers some tantalizing, Ethiopian-inspired bar bites, including: Spicy Lentil Sambu (pastry filled with lentils, scallions, ginger, garlic & fresh chili); Meatballs topped with blue cheese; Arangodi (Spinach dip with garlic, serrano pepper, ranch mayo and capers); and Bourbon Glazed Sausage Sliders. All of these items are $10 or less and perfect for sharing. If you're looking for a more substantial meal, Sheba has a dinner menu. No dish on the menu is more than $15.  So if you're looking for a cool place to grab a drink before or after seeing a movie at the Kabuki, swing by Sheba Lounge. You'll be glad you did.

pfHICN67xeftkMIJyrvsIQ.review_text: Delicious. Absolutely delicious!  Must.... come... back... soon! When there is live music!

UvmKLvE5_OCRrzFcuCFJYg.review_text: Our service was pretty bad, but the server was so nice (it counts for something). The bathroom which we were seated by started flooding and the water started heading to our table, which is not only distracting, but... well, gross.   When the bathroom water reached our table, our server reseated us in a more "rural" location. The move was appreciated, but we didn't really see her much after that.   With that said, we really enjoyed the food. I would say the top two things we ordered, that I absolutely would go back for, are the kitfo and the meat sambussa.   We ate on the early end. This was a weekend night and the music was just starting as we were leaving, so I am only reviewing Sheba as a restaurant and not as a night club.

r7OgNNr2JgMVmfcP1Q76yw.review_text: Service: Very friendly and welcoming staff. Everytime I go there, the owner always makes me feel very comfortable. She is a pleasant and hospitable lady.  Food: I was firstly introduced to Ethiopian food from dinning here. We ordered a few appetizers and entrees. Meatballs was one of my favorites. The meat was tender and well seasoned. It just melted in your mouth. Sirloin sambusa was my new discovery for the love of Ethiopian food. The beef was perfectly cook with a slight hint of spiciness. It was exquisite. Lega Tips (entree) was very delicious too. I cant describe enough love here for Sheba Piano Lounge.   Ambience: very cozy and live music was a great touch to lift up the dinning experience.  I highly recommend anyone who is seeking a dynamic uplifting dinning experience. Sheba Piano Lounge wont disappoint you!!!

c--TE-tUiQomDvHKyGHFTQ.review_text:
This place is a rare find for SF.
  Nice lounge/restaurant/bar located in the Filmore.  Went on a Tuesday.  Overall, I like this place.  Seems like it would be a great lounge to visit on a Fri/Sat night, however they don't have a DJ, only a live piano player (weekend).  With a DJ this place could be a great lounge.
  Ambiance/Atmosphere:
 Nice decor, comfortable couches, classy/kickback atmosphere, good place to chill with friends.  Bar has flat screen TVs.  Owner says that the place is full on Fri/Sat.
  Food:
 1) Spicy Pomegranate Chicken drummetts are really good (100 times better than your typical buffalo wings).
 2) We ordered the chicken (Doro Tibs), simmered beef and sirloin/shrimp...good but not great...I think they needed a little more salt.
  Drinks:
 Wine list and full bar.  Drinks were average (according to my friends)...I just had a Cranberry Juice that they charged $4 for!!!!  I thought that was a little ridiculous.
  Service:
 Went on a Tues night and only one lady was working the bar, dining area, lounge and also was the hostess.  The place was not very busy so that one lady had it under control.  Service was a little slow, but as soon as you got that one lady's attention, she was very friendly and prompt to take care of you.  
  The place is owned by 2 Ethiopian sisters.  One of the owners came to our area to make sure everything was fine.  It was.
  Again, if they dump the piano and get a DJ, this could be the best lounge in SF (depending on the crowd).

24fBj8CPh83y7PDkKGkukA.review_text: I love ethiopian food and wanted to try some in city. Searched on Yelp and found Sheba.
