I was intrigued by the combination of Ethopian food, live jazz/blues music and the lounge. Decided to give it a try.  I went there with a friend of mine on a Friday evening at around 7:30 PM. It had a nice lounge with restaurant. It was crowded and we had to wait for around 20+ mins to get a table. In the meanwhile we enjoyed some cocktails at the bar. The decor is great with some exotic colors. The live music started at I think around 8:30 PM or so. The place is small and can get crowded as the night progresses. We ordered the samboosas and veggie combo. As is the case in many Ethiopian places, the service is little slower, but not too bad. Food was slightly less spicy to me but spice was right for my friend. Overall the food was delicious.  After dinner we hung out there in the lounge for a while enjoying the music. Live Jazz music and the lounge are what separates rest of the Ethiopian places from this.

On_LwosTn_kdTRQnsggUaQ.review_text: A group of four of us arrived just a few minutes before closing and they were more than willing to take us in and let us order from a full menu! This shouldn't come as a shock seeing as their a restaurant and sell food but you would be surprised (or not surprised) at how many restaurants roll their eyes, make you feel guilty, give you a bad attitude or just refuse to serve you if you show up a few minutes before closing. The bartender and owner were so friendly and accommodating!!:) Guess I've been going to the wrong restaurants!  Now for the food! Like many reviewers on here, I have never tried Ethiopian food before and I couldn't be more pleased! The four of us split the vegetarian sampler and a lamb dish (we weren't that hungry), the lamb was so ridiculously tender and juicy and the vegetarian sampler was absolutely delicious, and left a delightful after taste in my mouth for hours, I think it was all the unique & subtle spices that the vegetables were cooked in, so so so good!   It was a Saturday night when we went and their was an awesome band with a very talented lead singer, even my boyfriend who is very critical when it comes to music (sometimes too critical) was very impressed! Great food, great service, great music, and great atmosphere, can't wait to come back!

RPD2MK_RJbCY_GFsLAZjig.review_text: Quite tasty...had dinner here Wednesday night place was empty but nicely decorated with earth tones. Tends to be busy on the weekends according to the bartender. Full liquor and Ethiopian food.

EgvES8rWgKa5x9vAfMU6Yw.review_text: Had some time to kill before a movie so my girlfriend and I popped in here.  Nice server, not super expensive but I didn't really care for the food that much (maybe I'm not an Ethiopian food sort of guy)... I ordered a spicy chicken dish but it wasn't very spicy.... didn't really like the bread that was served to scoop up your meal....  Anyways, it didn't do much for us.

xGDcXcscWQl_X0R3f1LIzw.review_text: Sheba's Piano Lounge (SPL) is a fantastic place and really brings an otherwise boring part of fillmore some needed flare. You'll often hear live jazz music from outside with people enjoying their delicious ethiopian food or wine near their fire place inside or enjoying each others company on their outdoor patio. Indoors you'll find a dimly lit, lively vibe which is perfect for date night or winding down with your friends. Outdoors you'll find several table adjacent to the restaurant itself. The food is incredible and intimate (since Ethiopian food tends to be eaten with your hands and potentially shared). For folks that want to try ethiopian food but have a limited palate I'd recommend beef tibs and for those that want to try the hardcore traditional ethiopian food I'd recommend kitfo prepared rare. Sheba's can get packed on the weekend so make sure you book a reservation in advance. Enjoy!

PUPb7ahTlJ44qZLGSHAfRw.review_text: Wow! I REALLY enjoyed my meal here. Good starter before heading to Yoshi's. I've come several times to watch my friend's jazz band play--ECQ--they're great, contact me for bookings! Also catch them @ Bubble Lounge every Friday.  FOOD:~The vegetarian platter was so tasty & not too heavy. Each & everything was yummy, especially the salad (the dressing really wowed my mouth), with the bread rolls.  ~The steak tartare is so yummy & unique & different--I'm drooling just thinking of it.  DECOR: Uh...a little too faux for me. I guess one wall is a replica of the owner's church in Ethiopia, which is cool.  SERVICE: Ok.  BATHROOM: Ok. Cute funky sink in the hallway.  OVERALL: I will definitely be back for that steak tartare & veg platter.

bXjywxQEN-TPs99IG2s6EA.review_text: Eh. Forgetable. You know it's a bad sign when you can make almost everything they serve you can make at home for way less than half the price.   I mean the baked goat chesse was so mediocre and it was served with the random assortment box of crackers you can buy at Whole Foods.  Worth $9?  Hardly!  Meat sambusa nothing memorable.  Spicy pomegranate chicken drummettes were deff not spicy and didn't taste like pomegranate. $13 so not worth it.    Also had the Ethopian veggie sampler and concluded, I am not big on Ethopian.   Not Sheba's fault though.  If I liked it, I probably would have enjoyed the veggie plate.  Seriously, nothing memorable.   You know it's an extra bad sign whe your bf has to remind you you went out to dinner the night before and you pause and think for a minute or so before you can even remember where you ate.  So sad!  It's soo close but soo not worth going back.

OLBVur3Bo2Bqy05ngDf0wA.review_text: Love that place .... Love it.  Went there on short notice, and yelp rating that suggested this place to be nice.  and yes it was.  As soon as we walked in, we saw the live music band playing close to the entrance way, a smooth and chill jazz sounds that makes you just want to sit down and relax, and so we did.  Both my wife and I ordered the Penne pasta and they were actually pretty good.  we followed that with the tiramisu cake, which was also pretty darn good.  what I did like about the place the most however was the level of friendliness and professionalism the staff had.  WE WILL BE BACK FOR SURE :-)

GHFU3rZnYLF0MdJPYhMweA.review_text: I REALLY like this place. Mixed crowd and some good jazz. Small place but big enough to have a lot of fun.

H0eXmOJkHt6o-ER8EjyDNw.review_text: The food was very, very tasty. I had the Mesir Wat- it was very delicious, but I would have liked a little more spice to the dish. The atmosphere was fantastic- my friend and I were there early and there were some people playing guitar in the lounge just chillin and it was pretty cool. I also had a Sheba Cosmo which was fantastic. I felt sorry for our server, she was the only one serving and got our tabs confused and it took us a good 10 minutes to sort it all out. Honestly, I don't think  Sheba Lounge can hold a candle to Demara in Oakland, but if you can't- or don't-  go across the bay, Sheba is a great spot to go...

c4bNOJ5XnKKoHJoQE4zrcQ.review_text: I am not expert but this is delicious! The atmosphere is great - live music on the weekends and a cozy fireplace if you want to relax. The vegetarian platter is definitely enough for 2 and then you can add! Drinks are reasonably price and its a great dinner spot for before a move at Kabuki theater.

6y84tqGNWyV4-7UsuJLuPw.review_text: My group and I had a wonderful time!  Highly recommend this gem in the Fillmore!  Pros:  -Warm, attentive service -Unique decor -Cool crowd -Well made, well spiced food -Variety of authentic offerings -AWESOME music  Cons:  -Somewhat pricey -Tight seating -Tough to be able to choose your seating in regards to viewing the music -Small portions

yrFkZTQJoJZh0sA2D0Hcww.review_text: I live upstairs from this place and my friends and I call this the "Should Have Gone Home" Lounge because we always end up here at 1:30 in the morning when we really should have gone straight home upstairs. But they serve hard alcohol and snacks til really late.  The food at this place is really good too.  The meatball appetizer is the best.

zdRpRPiXFL4JZGZsgiZLQg.review_text: Extra star cuz dey got liquor.. ahh, yeah.

7cw0UdBUiAnqyocYw42IVg.review_text: Really enjoyed this place. Live music and great ethnic food. Ask for Derek the bartender. He's great on suggestions and fast service. He had great suggestions on what the "newbie" (me) should try. Suggested Mushroom Sambussa and Lega Tibs which were very tasty.

vTbQZNz8FH4jcrni7Vkl1Q.review_text: "... best lentils you can possibly have"  The Jazz - on the night we visited was a hit. Fun, fast instrumental Latin beats were excellent and a great start to our night.  The food - not being a huge fan of pureed food items i have to concede that the lentils  - in Mesir Wat are truly inspiring. Having had it at least on 2 occasions I wouldn't hesitate to order it a third time.  The drinks -  Selassie - tastes like licorice which is impossible to discern from the drinks menu. Besides that an excellent African food destination.  Added bonus - overhearing a conversation of a couple on a 1st date in a table next to ours.  This epic example of social astuteness and emotional intelligence (or maybe EPIC trolling) in story form, featured an arrest for burglary, a six month stint in the clink, accusations of mental illness, a show and tell of a sketchbook with cool anime inspired cartoons. The gentleman seemed unphased, even after a story of some undesired sex followed by an abortion.  I think it had something to do with his time spent the Israili Army.

_SVfoi3YUFNHswsfZUO9mg.review_text: Posh!  Far more fanciful than I expected upon hearing "jazz lounge", though I was told to dress it up a bit for the evening (... I've been told I clean up well... which alludes that I'm rather scrub-tastic otherwise?).  Sheba is an unassuming little location, comfortably seating/dining 50(ish), but roomy enough, with standing room for mingling and cocktails, to entertain large, casual groups...  The decor is warm and organic, modern in its accouterments of sleek black leather chairs, darkly tanned leather couches and Avant-Garde cocktail tables assembled in view of a glass-front fireplace.  Another lounge area is flanked by a centerpiece/dividing wall of architectural flourish reminiscent of 15th or 16th century Islamic influence.  Dining tables for small dining parties (2-6 people) occupy the remainder of the restaurant, with a full featured bar at one end, and a [Baby Grand?] piano at the other.  Gathering for a casual meet-and-greet, we indulged in a few appetizers and drinks while a pianist and a soprano saxophonist exhuberantly riff'd free form jazz in the corner...  - Spicy Lentil Sambussa w/ Tangy Dip - $ 6.00 - delicate pastry filled with lentils, scallions, ginger, garlic & fresh chili  - Spicy Meatballs - $ 7.00 - coated w/ blue cheese  - Spicy Pomegranate Chicken Drummettes - $ 8.00 -  seasoned with an Ethiopian herb, Awaze sauce  The food was enticing and ventures into atypical/uncommon flavors (at least from my usual tasting experiences) and leaves a lasting/remarkable impression.  The "spicyness" of our appetizers was subtle and potent without being obnoxious or deriding from the tastes.  Quite a palate broadening experience...  The bar (...who,me?  drink?...) is fairly stocked and fairly priced, offering a wide array of wines, beers, and liquors.  I also had a chance to purvey a glass or two of Ethiopian Honey Wine... very nice finish.  All in all, Sheba is a great option as a jumping off point to start a weekend night roaming about Fillmore. __________________________________________ The tall, slinky waitress with the undeniable switch and sway in her walk... yum!

dQFiETbHfM6wXXpNAFAzZQ.review_text: Absolutely fabulous Ethiopian cuisine.  The best I've ever tasted.  Each dish we tried was uniquely spiced and flavorful.  We particularly liked the home-spawned recipes - each dish was a family recipe or tradition.  The vegetarian samosa appetizers were delicious and a prelude of things to come.  We also loved the garbanzo beans and the beef stews.  And the jazz pianist provided a great background atmosphere.   And for dessert, the baklava is a must-try.  We are definitely coming back to this SF jewel.

wCaRoHsqyCZfLh3aVxbpng.review_text: Maybe it was the fact that it was a Sunday, but this place gets a 3 AT BEST!  We arrived, seated quickly, waited 15 min for drinks and another 10 for food service.  The food was just OK.  My wife and I have done better at home and we've had much better Ethiopian elswhere.  Hopefully they do better on weekdays and Saturdays

_zdzxeqKqE6udAiS4X-38Q.review_text: Live jazz, relaxed ambiance, delicious food and affordable prices? I'm there! Loved Sheba, will stop by whenever I am in SF!

ghQZvTiGa5M6v_j2lrtFfQ.review_text: "cozy ambiance + live music = repeat customer"  Love this place~!! It's my culinary and musical solace from stressful world.  Discovered this place and been coming back ever since.  Great beer selection and just love the live music.  Looking for cozy place?  They have a fire place where you can sit and enjoy your love ones.  Highly recommended..

To5pT_SdI7qthLalXDuoZA.review_text: Ethiopian food and Jazz!  What else could someone need?  I love Sheba.  I have been coming here for quite sometime and if I am in the Fillmore it is likely I'm going to at least pop in for a drink and listen to some live jazz.  The food here is amazing so if you find yourself in the area and you are hungry, you will not be disappointed.  It is bit pricey but well worth the experience.  Sheba would also serve as a great date location so all of you singles out there keep this place in mind.  Tip: Show up right before the first band plays.  You will get a table easily (it is a small place), and right when your food arrives you will be treated to some great jazz!

fC5qwh1Pm1mMFl2toUz6sw.review_text: Popped in here for a quick Monday night drink because it was the first place I saw after wandering around outside of the movie theater on Geary.  What a hidden gem!  I did not order any food, because we arrived pretty late, (hence the 3-star review...just can't say yet!) but I will be back to try the nosh soon.  The bartender whipped up some wonderful cucumber martinis, and we listened to live jazz jam sessions with some of the friendliest and most talented musicians I have ever seen perform.  If you happen to play an instrument, Monday nights are designated jam sessions, and anyone can drop by and lay down some sweet, sweet, jazz sounds.  Also a great place to pick up a jazz musician (young or old) in between sets, if you're into that sort of thing.  ;-)  Who isn't?

5_w7gXS2q4oZneGWloS_3Q.review_text: An Ethiopian Piano bar just down the street from The Fillmore - great place to stop before a show there. Warm, cozy lounge area with fireplace and comfy chairs, a separate bar area, and seating for dinner. You can also just order food from the bar and have it brought to you in your comfy chairs by the fireplace. :)   The staff here are very friendly, the cocktails unique, tasty and strong (I had the "X boyfriend" and it was delicous!), and the food quite tasty!!! Between the 4 of us last night, we shared 2 apps and 2 ethiopian entrees, and that was plenty of food.  They take pride in their food here. My top rec in terms of food are the MEATBALLS with blue cheese. Excellent!

Mz8UNnWUNs__JObPLtw06Q.review_text: We had a great New Years 2013 here .great food !! Derek was a great server

SpwyrRyFusOCBTgb7dVTKw.review_text: Live Music, Tasty Ethiopian, Amazing Service!  What's not to love!    Try the Sambussa and their Champagne Cocktail made with Ethiopian Bitters.

D1LeNWYRYX5Y3QU501k3tQ.review_text: I came here with my bf a few months ago, and it was our first time having Ethiopian food. We didn't really know what to expect but we were excited to try something different.  We ordered the spicy sambussas as an appetizer, which reminded me of eggrolls but spicy and very flavorful. The dipping sauce was really tasty too.  For our entree, we ordered the vegetarian sampler and lamb, which was all really good.  The Ethiopian bread they give you to eat with the food was a bit weird for me... kinda moist and bland.  But it was definitely interesting to try and tasted good with the sampler.    The delicious food and jazz band entertaining us throughout the night made it a great evening for the both of us.  I highly recommend this place to anyone who likes to try different food and can appreciate the sounds of a live jazz band.

ACUVZ4SiN0gni7dzVDm9EQ.review_text: Sheba is a really interesting place. They serve Ethiopian food. They have live jazz. And they shoot for a neighborhood bar feeling. I happen to think they do all 3 of these things pretty well, which makes me a fan of this spot. That and the friendly workers that are here.  Everything I've tried food-wise has been spicy. It could have been just what I was ordering though. And truthfully I haven't had that much food. I actually really love stopping by on blustery nights with Sir Nicholas, ordering a glass of Ethiopian honey wine, and cozying up be the fire. You can control if it's on or off so if it gets too hot you just flip a switch and the same goes if it gets cold. It's a lovely nightcap on any evening.

1Var1BNP1Ksi8gpJQ_zgsg.review_text: Came here for my boy's bday on a monday it was legit. Live jazz music these guys were just jammin hard. The food was on point its all about the sheba burgers like whats good. Waitresses know whatsup. My dood was havin his bday here and they somehow figured it was his bday and brought him da cake. Swag. They also have fireplaces. I like warm.

BIFhDqxL9UXCMrA1SYriqw.review_text: This place was great.  Very good service, great food, and the music is good for eating.

Xf5KPJimu8cLFndTL8WPJQ.review_text: What a great combination -- amazing food + music + low-key, intimate environment. I'm officially in love with Sheba Piano Lounge! Located in the lower Fillmore, this place is an escape from the hustle and bustle outdoors, as you are transported into a serene, relaxed environment.  We shared the vegetarian sampler and the beg alecha -- tender pieces of lamb marinated in an Ethopian herb sauce. The meal was served with the traditional spongy, injera bread.   LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this cuisine. It's definitely an intimate way to have dinner with someone. Sheba Piano Lounge is also pretty much the perfect date spot!  I'll definitely be back to try some of the amazing chicken dishes on the menu, and to relax to some jazz music when in the mood.

FKvDywLpUoZ3mEgZTBYTqQ.review_text: 3 stars for the ambiance and the entertainment alone! I definitely say that Ethiopian food is definitely an acquired taste...the pasta pomodoro was very, very weird..definitely not my favorite...but it was nice to try...  I don't remember the name of the dishes we ordered but we got some beef ones and a chicken thigh one. The spongy bread is weird cause it has a weird texture, but I wanted to keep an open mind so I tasted it...not my favorite, but since Ethiopian food is not usually eaten with utensils, it really was my only option. I came with family so all of us eating with our fingers was not an issue but if I came with others who I weren't really close with, I think it would've been awkward. The food is good although I don't know if I'd choose to go there for food again, but maybe just drinks and to listen to the live entertainment. Definitely an experience...and a good one :)

QD0njdv5eHGFv6RyqML4RQ.review_text: Service is abysmal. What happened to the service? Waitresses are so unfriendly that I ended up fetching my own water and not once in 3 hours was I asked if everything was alright. Not once did they check up on my party. Bad service.  Food is second rate. The food that I paid for was not worth $40, more like $10 at most. There was nothing special about the food and it was plain as jane. Uninteresting and unpalatable. There is NOTHING special about the food, I had zero expectations and it still did not satisfy me.

5oew4bMRuhDId4Yt0VbSqg.review_text: Sheba Piano Lounge stole my heart. In addition now they have opened up their doors to great new events. myspace.com/soulfulsunda… COME CHECK US OUT!

5qdxr9G_VUkPWMK5lwUfoA.review_text: I found this place randomly on a Saturday night-- Good find! The bartenders were super friendly and the drinks were delicious. There was a great live jazz band. Not too packed, good prices. Very nice!

yz0s55qwi_WqVjmbyZ9ICw.review_text: We were looking for a bar with drinks and music, but not food. Sheba serves food, but we came after dinner.  Bar: Friendly staff, comfortable seating along with a fireplace, and a laid back environment.  Drinks: They have a cocktail list which we tried the "Abyssian Storm" which is a play on a Dark & Stormy with rum, ginger beer, and lime. It was average. The liquor selection is limited. I had a Pig Whistle rye whiskey which was unbalanced.  Music: The music wasn't up to form for true jazz lovers, but decent if looking for a lounge act. They have music on weeknights like on the Monday we were there along with plenty of seating at 9P. No cover.

1C0lvOrlq1JSe-e8yPOzSQ.review_text: Went in for a pre Yoshi's show snack and had the lentils sambussa and sliders. They were both delish. The sambussa has a spicy dipping sauce. Something in there started numbing my cheeks and tongue! A little unnerving but soooo tasty. I mentioned it to the waiter and he asked after my health - allergies and whatnot - very professional. Apparently not that uncommon a comment.  Thanks for looking out for your customers, kind sir.

VkHvY873uNxc5nl-WSiNiw.review_text: This is my first time writing a full review for a restaurant/bar and I feel compelled of doing it, since this restaurant/bar exceeded my expectation...I have been to places that I really like and wanted to write reviews but I never felt taking time to write the review. This one though really earns my first review...so we wanted to go to a Jazz bar in Filmore, but since Yoshi's was so busy that night we walked around and ended up here...as soon as I walked in the restaurant, something smelled sooooo good!! mind you that I already had a full dinner just half an hour earlier, but the smell was sooo delicious that me and my boyfriend decided to order some appetizer to try out...we noticed that many table ordered some kind of appertizer plate, so we asked the server and got the vegetarian platter...OMG it was soo delicious seriously the food was soo good, there were 5 different things on the platter but everything was so tasty...I especially loved the pickle cabbage (I'm not sure if it's pickle but it tasted like it), there was lentil, and also collard greens, and some kind of red beans...anyway the food was sooo delicious and generous portion for cheap price...also the band was playing WHOLE night, by whole night I mean they play until 1am, very dedicated musicians, I can tell they just enjoy playing it for the crowd...I really enjoyed my first experience here, very pleased with the music and the food, and will come back soon to try other things on their menu and enjoy beautiful Jazz music...  P/s: even though the delicious smell was all over the place, and the restaurant/bar was relatively small, surprisingly when we got home, my hair and body didn't smell like food at all....they must have really good ventilator, which is a plus, since I don't really like smelling like food...

XjZVVa77YGfSudwbGqpEFQ.review_text: Good music and food but lost one star because wait staff not very knowledgeable of what is gluten free on the menu. Caused lots of post-prandial grief with my friend. Otherwise, good place to go for good eats and tunes.

EtaG4IWkEUalOdNSQnMEdA.review_text: I work across the street and this tends to be our watering hole. It's so much more than that though! The owner is so gracious. She always gives us complimentary pita chips and dip.  The space is beautiful. I always come too late to hear the live music, but i'm sure it's great.  Love ya Sheba!

BoyxYPrXrj3ru8m_8ooGGg.review_text: Went here during our staycation to San Francisco. I wanted to do something low key, with good drinks and a cool low key vibe. So i did a bit of research here on yelp and stumbled accross this highly rated/reviewed jazz lounge.   We went on a Friday evening and found parking with ease. No cover charge which was a plus. Once we got in, we were so very lucky to find seats at the bar because it was packed. Its not a very big place but there are seats outside. I must say that I love the vibe here. Its predominantly an ethiopian restaurant and they play live music throughout the week at 9. We unfortunately didnt try their food. To be honest, they are very light handed when it comes to drinks.   Overall, i enjoyed myself and am very eager to come back and try their food. Update to come.

9uhOuCTlULaxLZj_j8KWHw.review_text: My girl & I ventured here a few weeks ago and were very pleasantly surprised! Was  a Friday night and we went for Ethiopian food and jazz. I was able to reserve 2 comfy chairs which gave us the perfect view for when the Quartette came to play. Actually being able to reserve a couch like chair was so cool! Neither of us had ever been, but we had heard about it. Got there about an hour and a half before they played which was far too long, but for a Friday night it was barely packed. Didn't get crowded till 11ish. I have had Ethiopian food many times and agree with other reviewers that it's much pricier here than a standard Ethiopian restaurant, but this is not a standard Ethiopian restaurant. At a standard one you'd pay around $10 for a huge vegetarian combo platter and here it was around $14 for a smaller one, but still more than enough to fill two people up with all the Injera. All good and would order again. Also got the Sambussa's which were good, but not great and so hot that even at the very last bite we could barely put it in our mouths. I got a cocktail with Espresso liquor in it which was not good at all. Could only get thru half. My girl got a ginger infused one which she said was good. Wouldn't get a cocktail again, though. Service was very attentive till we needed our bill. Ambiance was awesome! Comfy, quaint, eclectic, and super jazzy. The music was perfect and we'd definitely go back. Don't let the cheesy neon light decorations outside the place deter you. This is a classy place and super romantic!

ItmZ_Y27bWpDx3E_nf6j2A.review_text: This place reminds me of a dimly lit livingroom, but in a good way.  Inside there are couches and armchairs and then there's a piano near the entrance.  Only if you go to the very back will you see the typical bar area.  This neighborhood has plenty of parking so driving shouldn't be a problem.  You may not find room to sit inside, but there's also an outdoor patio area.  The sweet wine is good and next time I'll try the food.  Good find and worth a visit.

tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ.review_text: 01.26.10  Comfy and cozy decor.  Cute and fresh restroom.  Grab a beer, sit by the fire, and you're good to go.  Nice place to stop by before or after a Yoshi's show.  Or a Fillmore concert.  Or after dinner.  Etc.?

HxEySTkc-e2vg3Nmv2uzYg.user_location: St Pete Beach, Tampa Bay, FL
HxEySTkc-e2vg3Nmv2uzYg.review_text: I've kind of been dreaming of this place since we came here the other weekend.  It's totally not what I was expecting as far as atmosphere goes.  The music style didn't match the cuisine, I guess?  Whatever, it works.    The thing I like BEST?  Nothing is over $15.  And it's good food.  We had the spicy sambussas to start.  Both of our dishes (I didn't even try to remember the name) were great and I can't wait to go back for more.   The tables are close together so that's kind a bummer if you don't want your neighbors to hear you or if you have an eavesdropping problem like we do.  (what? we can't help it!)  We went to the loungey side after dinner and got a couple of drinks.  Honey wine...not what I expected (gross).  The pink dragon fruit one was great though.

fcnaLf9n35xD9mQjJ773ug.review_text: I really liked this place! I've had Ethiopian before, but this place was much, much better. They were very busy when we came in so we sat at the bar... I would have loved a table. But we still had a great time. Service was good, a little slow. But good...   We had the veggie app. sampler, the egg roll thingy (OK in my opinion, nothing special) and the catfish stew, which was delicious. Aside from the egg rolls which I would not order again, (don't remember what they're called, but that's what they were! Ready made wonton dough and all..) Everything was fresh and delicious. The live music was a nice added bonus. I also loved the decor inside.. I would definitely return the next time we go to Yoshi's....I also LOVED the house pineapple cocktail. I would go back just for that!   And trust me, I'm an elite :))

ZKdNk5RYb9ZgYYIS01FUrw.review_text: Took my sister here for a late birthday dinner.  The owner is RIDICULOUSLY NICE! We wanted to try out the vegetable platter & get two entrees but he told us it would've been too much food for just two of us, so he had the chef add some veggies on the sides of our entrees.    It was our first time trying out Ethiopian food & I would say overall, it's good if you've never had it before.  The lamb was hands down the best dish.  The catfish wasn't anything special.   We didn't get a chance to stay & listen to the live music, but I'll bring the boyfriend back to see how the night life is.    If you've never had Ethiopian food & feel like being adventurous, try it out!

S6YAAf5cHG1sBckZHScWMw.review_text: We popped in here for an early dinner before a show at Yoshi's across the street.   The food has extremely interesting flavors. I loved eating with my hands (and that crepe/bread they serve you). Definately recommend the vegetarian sampler, which offers a wide selection of vegetable dishes to compliment your protein of choice.   The wait staff are very friendly and are a testament to the repeat busines they get here - all the tables around us seemed to be returning as they reguarly do.   Prices were very reasonable.  Give it a go!

dgYX0NldzC3uXcZrq-XfdA.review_text: I suppose that in the simple act of passing by a place that draws one in so thoroughly that upon entering, time ceases to exist would be a place that would justify obsessive re-visits. This quaint little lounge teeters on the edge of something wonderful or in the very least, reminiscent. Maybe it wasn't the Sheba Lounge at all that offered this presence but the music drifting out into the Fillmore night. I walked in with my friend and sipped a glass of Merlot, the whole time wondering if Oscar Peterson  felt the same chills when playing perfectly executed overtones .The food couldn't compare to the mid-range explorations, but it was good enough.

ibRTPCNETk1DIUku4Ccc8g.review_text: Ugg. My favorite Ethiopian Restaurant in all of SF. Delish/fresh food, live piano, low lighting ambiance, strong drinks. And everything comes out on a huge plate to share. Eat with your hands! Great for a girls night out, or a sweet date. Walkable to the Kabuki Theater to catch a movie after. Hands down one of my fav spots.  Vegetable Sampler: Kik Alicha, Mesir Wat Meat: Lamb, Prime Beef, Sirloin Tips, Doro Tibs Chicken Drinks: All the champagne options are tasty + add flavors!

BJYaU73D-IoYo-7DV1-Xug.review_text: A wonderful, warm, delicious evening for those who love spicy food, those who don't, and those like me who do but whose digestive tracts don't!  The food is delicious,  lovingly prepared with the best ingredients, and runs the gamut from a delicious vegetarian penne pasta (my favorite, I'm a vegetarian), to sea bass, delicious salads with Netsanet's secret dressing, AND the traditional Ethoipian platter served with all the injera you can eat which is also delicious and can be tweaked  to accommodate herbivores, carnivores OR omnivores.    Sheba's owner, the beautiful Netsanet, has truly put her heart and soul into this special place, a cozy gem in the Fillmore!   I go there to eat, but there is also a very inviting bar/lounge area with seductive overstuffed leather chairs, a fireplace and low tables.  The bar menu looks delicious as well.    And to top it off, there is live music!

1d-s7hZ-uR6Uzg2iDVN4jw.review_text: First time for Ethiopian food. It was very good, although I was with an beautiful girl from Eritrea (next to Ethiopia) who said that the injera wasn't quite right.  I liked it. They also have a sweet Ethiopian wine that is very good.

U2xsIRAZzMGuFYQgqihCSA.review_text: Food: I went safe with the Penne pasta dish, and it wasn't that great. I ended up having to zest it myself with salt and quite of bit of parmesan. For desert I ordered the Tiramisu and it was bland.  Drinks: I dont drink, but I went with an enthusiast who said the 10 year Lapharoaig was decadently smokey.  Music: Easy jazz, which was nice if you happen to go with someone who hasn't yet developed an ear for it. It's not overpowering, but enough to fill the lounge with ambience. The interesting thing was, the performers werent trying to steal me from my conversations. Their attitude was relaxed and patient, which had me enjoying myself.  Service: Friendly, nice, and informative.

Mc2C3uVVCUvMkLWFlyToZw.review_text: So, I hadn't had Ethiopian food in a long while, and after an ordeal to try to catch a cab to Sheba Piano Lounge, I was really really looking forward to the dinner.  I got the vegetarian sampler, which had the usual in it.  I also got their spicy fries as a hold me over snack.  The fries were pretty tasty, and the sampler itself was okay.. just not hot enough and a bit of a disappointment there.  The ambiance was pretty awesome though.. dimly lit with a live band.. it was nice.  Random note: there's a really nice wine bar right around the corner that you should go to if you're looking to continue your night post dinner.

Z88N6qly3Dp5C06XbZ9IMQ.review_text: If the Manny Pacquaio doppelganger would only stop checking out the chicks here, then he could've probably made me a stronger Tanqueray and Tonic.

M4OZcoLHydGc-M5TTE5Qpg.review_text: Really like this place but am truly bummed that Doro Wat has been taken off the menu and Doro Tibs, the only other chicken entree, is a total letdown.  The chicken dishes used to be delicious because they were slow cooked for hours, and now the only chicken dish is quickly sauteed and tastes dry.    Portion sizes differ depending on the day of the week...which makes the dining experience a bit hit or miss.  Usually "hit," but it seems some corners are being cut.  Sad.

BBSYyLG824fZjP-kulhLgw.review_text: I stopped by for a drink with a friend here...didn't have the space to try any of the food, but wanted to check it out. It's very cozy, has plush sofas, and a nice warm fireplace. The waitress/bartender was attentive and checked on us frequently, even though we only had a few drinks. It was a Tuesday night and when we got there, there was a pianist/singer singing and playing to some tunes. It's cool, I would come back-i'd like to try the food.

WzDcKl7HOq2Dj3R86gH7ww.review_text: the night we went, there was nobody playing the piano. so in a sense, i was kind of disappointed. i mean, isn't this place known for their live music? c'mon!  ah, well. the food was good, albeit SPICY! i could only eat the "ethiopian hummus" and the chicken dish. even the pomegranate chicken drummettes were too spicy for me. the beef was a little tough, too.   the atmosphere is very nice, and i liked that it wasn't crowded and loud like some places can get. i ordered a pomegranite martini and it was way too strong (for me), so the waitress got it diluted w/more of the mixer for me.  the bathroom is clean, and we were lucky and found street parking. if you want good ice cream, go across the street to miyako old fashioned ice creamery (i think that's what it's called) and indulge yourself.

XLpeJe2HV2jvFkyX-pAsIQ.review_text: Beautiful piano music, nice decor, large tables...  Food is lovely and large portions.  Try the sea bass.  Made with Ethiopian spices and served big enough for two.  Then try the veggie sampler.  Loved the messer wot (lentil stew),  Injera could be better but does not merit taking a star away.    Order a dinner salad with the secret dressing.  Ummmmm....perfect for dinner for two or three.  Didn't try dessert...:(

giIbI7SpTuO2kdZFrh_B1g.review_text: I'd always walked by this place but for some reason (I think it's the neon sign out front - just made it look tacky) I never went in. Yesterday a friend highly recommended the food, so off we went. I must say, I loved it. The food was great (and I've been to several Ethiopian restaurants), and the ambience more so. Live music, cozy fireplace and artsy walls. I tried the veggie sampler plate, loved the mesir wat (spicy lentils).  Will definitely be back! But I hope they get rid of the neon sign outside... I'm sure there are classier signs a nice restaurant/lounge can put up.

RwF_pu86MqSMAWeFFg410g.review_text: If it weren't for the AWFUL service, this place would've gotten 5 stars... Went there a few weeks ago on a Wednesday night and they only had ONE guy serving the entire place, including the bar.  He was literally jog-skipping around the restaurant from table to table.  Have to give him credit for his effort, but it was just ridiculous and kind of sad to watch. Given how good the food was (vegetarian sampler paired with the lamb was AMAZING!) and how many people were there on a weeknight, they can definitely afford to hire more help...  Perhaps this was just an unusual situation where they were short-staffed on short notice, so I'd still recommend the place.

FGBTSAcFcUBLztp5GMZVIw.review_text: I really wanted Sheba Lounge to be an over the top experience, especially because their decor put me in the mood to have a down right ethereal Ethiopian meal.   Whoever did the interior design for this place nailed the ambiance and layout. Private dining area to the far right. Dark wood, rich fabrics, and huge plush chairs lead up to the bar in the back. If I had come here just to hang out and have a drink, I think I would have had a better experience.  I was pleased with half the dishes we ordered. Tasty, but nothing exceptional. Their Injera, that I usually love so much, felt very doughy and not light and tangy. I prefer it when the dishes are served right over the bread so that the flavors have been soaked into each bite. Because we were a big group, our baskets of bread emptied quickly. When bread is your main food utensil, you really need it!  What really ended my meal on a disappointed note was the live music. We left at 10:30 just when the Jazz trio was starting to unload their gear. If it's a Friday night, you're a lounge with a location directly across from Yoshi's, AND it's Jazz you're treating your customers to, you gotta step up the tempo! Not sure if it was the band's tardiness or if they were just booked that late, but it made me feel like I didn't get the real experience of the "Lounge."  My suggestion, go for the drinks & ambiance and go late!

gNZ39-5Cwqhn7TG_zTYcgA.review_text: Simply the best of the best..!!! I am loving this, the service is great and the food is spectacular.. My new mainstay.  The ambiance is great too.. I will be bringing all my friends here for sure.

PVFekEJidqcH3V55HqhIBg.review_text: what an awesome place! the service was chill and we got seated right when we walked through the door. you have the option of eating at a table or in one of their loungey "living room" setting areas in front of an electric fire place. the food was so rich in flavor and i loved trying a little bit of everything. i split a vegetable combo platter along with 3 meat dishes with my table of 4 people total, and we were able to just barely finish all the food.   i think one of the best parts of eating here is the atmosphere, so when you come here you should plan on taking your sweet time. it's so homey and warm, you can't help but feel comfortable as you sit back eating from a huge shared dish with your friends while listening to live jazz music. i will definitely come back for another relaxing, delicious dinner.

WvTANiWPYRMSAY_TXTFHNQ.review_text: My girlfriend and I enjoyed this place and would return.  The food was great.  I can't comment on the typical ambiance because we ate quite early the the place was fairly quiet.  However, it seemed to pick up when we were finishing our meal.  Service was very attentive.  I'd return.

-89IDABrt2vnhvoCiUlVCw.review_text: I have only had an appetizer here, but it was delicious! The drinks? Even better! I got the Harrar Cooler and my boyfriend ordered a Mint Julep. The prices are decent as well, nothing on their menu was over $20.   I highly recommend going in early and setting up camp on the sofa in front of the fireplace. It is extremely comfortable, warm, with a hint of romance. The bartenders there are all super friendly too.

TMLVzNYs-zwwREudyvI08A.review_text: The bartender here is so ridiculously attractive that I pretty much act like Stan from South Park every time I go up to order a drink.  [vomits uncontrollably]  God I need to go have a cigarette after just thinking about her.  Oh, and the food and drinks are good too. ;p

saDYN_zBEoNheolWPh5RcA.review_text: Sheba Piano Lounge definitely tops the charts in terms of an amazing place to take out that special someone, enjoy awesome Ethiopian food, and listen to amazing live jazz music. The place is quite spacious, with plenty of lounge seating to watch the performances, and tables for those who want a more private dining space.  I came here with my girlfriend on a rainy Sunday evening. We were greeted by a really friendly executive chef: Netsanet Alemayehu, who checked up with us throughout the meal, providing excellent service and tips for our orders. Being my first time eating Ethiopian food, she wasn't hesitant to bring out her sample plate, and show us "how to properly eat Ethiopian!" :)  We ordered their Beg Alecha and their Doro Wat (special), and were blown away by how good the food was. The lamb in the Beg Alecha wasn't tough, and was packed with flavor.  The Doro Wat special was like a combination of the Doro Tibs and Tibs Wat - with chicken being the meat of choice. The chicken was so tender, and was such a delight to eat.  My girlfriend ordered a Gojam cocktail, and I ordered the Abyssinia Storm cocktail. They were both really good. The Gojam was really smooth, and was well sweetened by the Ethiopian Tej (honey wine) The Abyssinia Storm was also well made, blending Myers Dark Rum with lime juice and ginger beer. Intense for some, but lovely with such flavorful dishes! ;)  To round off such a wonderful night, the jazz performers (Bohemian Knuckleboogie) were great! A lot of lively music and a fair amount of slow jazz, keeping the ambiance really intimate and special for those dining at Sheba. Definitely an amazing experience when your ears are delighted by an amalgamation of piano, cello, drums/bongos, and guitar.  Overall, definitely an experience worth trying. If I find myself in the area, I will definitely make my way here again!

wCSlnMsSapVZfAJ-hKmKQA.review_text: There's a cool vibe in here and the Ethiopian food is very good; and don't take my word for it, my friend from Ethiopia comes here all the time. To me, I always prefer a slightly less chic feel when I'm eating this type of cuisine where you eat with your hands.  You can definitely find places in the East Bay and/or LA where you can get bigger portions for half the price and comparable quality. But I have nothing bad to say about the cook or the experience here. And the bar/live music gives it a hybrid feel.

-oTm4wx0HPig_PXnHgX2YA.review_text: Sheba's is the first place I ate at when I moved to the Bay Area and for my final meal as a San Franciscan, I could choose no other place than Sheba Piano Lounge.  Whenever I have eaten at Sheba's I have felt like family.  Netsanet and her staff are friendly and more than willing to help with menu selections and recommendations.  So let's talk food.  DELICIOUS.  I will be the first to admit that the menu is somewhat limited, however, the dishes that they do offer are super tasty.  I have never had a bad meal at Sheba's and having explored the menu extensively I can say that you cannot go wrong with any option.  Be sure to try to pomegranate & blue cheese meatballs - fantastic.  Let's talk ambiance.  There is definitely a romantic vibe to Sheba's, but it's good for just grabbing some cocktails w/friends.  With a rotating calendar of local musicians, no night is every the same at Sheba's.  And I LOVE that Sheba's is in the Fillmore.  If you aren't hanging out in the Fillmore then get with the program.  Sheba's is only one of the many great places to see and be seen in the Fillmore - GET FAMILIAR.

WbPrQlOtQsUC1kdeJBAfAQ.review_text: I've been to this place twice and I like it there. The staff here are very accommodating to set a table for us and also our gluten free requests. Although the food is better at the ones in Oakland, it's pretty good over all with nice atmosphere and music.

YcEt1ypaRVFDZ3BjCD4TCQ.review_text: Holy crap, the service. Granted, it was a Saturday night, but there seemed to be a lot of servers on the floor and not all seats were taken. When we arrived, our friends had already been waiting for water. An hour after that, after reminding servers repeatedly, we still had no water. They finally told us they were out of glasses. There were empty seats - how few glasses could a restaurant own? Let me make a trip to the dollar store for you. Two rounds of drinks came, slowly, before we got water.   We had four people at two small tables, so we asked for two vegetarian sample platters, one for each table. What came was a good amount of food for one person on each "platter." We assumed they would bring us enough food for four people, or at least ask us to clarify. I suppose that's mainly on us. The food was pretty good. The cabbage, potato, and carrot is always my favorite Ethiopian dish, and no disappointment here. Also, the staff was friendly. It was just the ridiculously long wait.

Z4SJfcKfnJfJzIdegIV_gA.review_text: I was really excited when this place opened, mostly because my apartment at the time was right on top of it (The Fillmore Center).  I was hardly disappointed.  It's a cool little joint with a true 'piano lounge' feel to it.  I'm sure that when Yoshi's opens this place will get the overflow, so go now while you can still almost always get a seat at the bar.  My only complaint would be that the drink prices are a bit steep, I experienced a little bit of 'sticker shock' when I got my tab.  I've never had the food, but I hear it's pretty good.

YBgoVgBt681vm2dZLUPN1Q.review_text: One of my 'hood' joints.  This place opened this year itself.  I discovered it not by sight, but by word.  I took my friend Antara to Rassela's (my last review) for dinner one night when her husband King wasn't back from work.  Unfortunately, it was 10 pm and they weren't serving anymore!  Wah.  But the lady is cool and says there's an Ethiopian place just one block down the street.  I was like "What?!  Really?"    So we proceed to walk down the street and enter this very cute/romantic restaurant with a piano sitting in one corner.  Another corner has a fireplace and some couches surrounding it.  There's an area of tables for diners, and a bar area as well.  We walk in and ask the bartender if food is still being served.  He was like "uh, well".  Then this lady sitting at the bar turns around and says, "Well, I'm the chef, so why not!"  How awesome!  So I don't know that there's a "close" time for the kitchen here.    I came another time with my friend Koji and they were playing piano/sax/vocal.  It was a bit loud, but still really chill and fun.  The dim lighting gives it a warm ambience.    And FYI- the proportions are HUMONGOUS.  Like, 5 times the amount I can eat in one sitting.  I'm not kidding.  And for those of you who know me, I eat a LOT.

ObitDzUawFrc6xdvdhJ_hA.review_text: A friend and I shared the Beg Alecha, lamb tasted pretty dry, the rest of the platter was just alright....I don't think it was worth it. I gave them one more star for the live music since they were fantastic.

JS8QELjMtrKKfGLX9L5Y-w.review_text: My friends, husband, and I were looking for something to do on a Saturday night where we could enjoy good food, a good atmosphere, and some music.  I found this place on yelp and had heard nothing about it, but still decided to give it a try.  Do yourself a favor and GO TRY IT! We went around 7:30 on a Saturday night and it was perfect timing.  Excellent service with our drinks and food coming at the perfect time, great food and drink recommendations, and we did not feel rushed at all.  We finished our meal right when the piano started playing (around 9) and stayed at our table for after dinner drinks.  Everything was amazing.  The only thing that I experienced was having some discomfort two days later on the toilet.  Sorry for TMI- but just thought I would warn you.  I would gladly go through that pain again to enjoy the food though!!

dTCEopG6rrF9n3kieG_L2A.review_text: + Cozy, dimly-lit & relaxed atmosphere + Fireplace lounge area w/ couches + Delicious lamb & kale dishes + Custom drinks from the bartender  I have been to here twice for dinner and once for after-dinner drinks. The dinner atmosphere is quiet and relaxed (read: no live music yet) and you can have a normal-voiced conversation and still be heard. Almost heard a little too well! The tables are spaced very closely, especially those along the wall. Our neighbors at the dinner table next to us could hear our every word and laughed at my best friend's claim that we will die in 20 years at the "ripe old age "of 45...  Right, the food..! We had the GOMEN (kale) and BEG ALECHA (spicy lamb stew) family style. Both were mighty tasty and my only complaint is that the portions seem small for the price ($8 and $15, respectively). They did present it quite well though - the lamb went in the middle of the injera (Ethiopian bread) platter and they separated the kale and side salads into two portions on either end of the plate. I appreciate that our waitress asked if we would like more injera (comes on another plate in rolls) when it looked like we were running low. I highly recommend the beg alecha. Well-seasoned, just the right amount of spicy, and tender, succulent lamb. Mm!  On a lounge + live music visit previously, the bartender on staff made me a custom grapefruit drink as I did not see any grapefruit-based drinks on the cocktail menu. If you're looking to drink something you don't see on the menu, just ask and they'll be able to whip something up just for you! I've also sampled the ETHIOPIAN "TEJ" HONEY WINE but I'm thinking this must be an acquired taste. It tasted a bit like whiskey with fermented honey and not something I'm accustomed to at all.   When the music starts, it gets loud! No more normal voices, you'll have to shout to get heard. But that's okay, the music makes up for it. Snag a spot on the couches by the fireplace and cozy up!

T1rP9rqslOh_72KI0IW7rQ.review_text: Came here for dinner with 6 of my coworkers and we had a great time! Making reservations was really easy. You can't tell from the outside, but the inside is a warm, relaxing, awesome place that you would feel comfortable eating dinner and then just hanging out in.  At first I was disappointed because I was expecting lots of injera, eating with hands, and giant family-style platters (this has been my experience at all the other places I've been to). But because it's a lounge, the entrees are meant for 1 person, and they also serve stuff like burgers and pasta. We ended up ordering some drinks -- the waiter was really nice, and let my friend try the honey wine because she wasn't sure about it. For food, we ended up ordering:  1. Spicy Lentil Sambussa (7.50, 4 pieces): All the Sambussas are like eggrolls that come in a small bowl. They are really good, and easy enough to cut into 2 small pieces (which we did, so that everyone could try each).  2. Sirloin Sambussa (8.50, 4 pieces): This one was definitely my favorite -- so flavorful! 3. Mushroom Sambussa (8.50, 4 pieces): This one was a close second favorite -- very savory and delicious.  4. Vegetarian Sampler (14.75): Not sure what exactly was in this, but the lentils, greens, and yellow mash were fantastic!! Each pile was small, but it came on the "family style Ethiopian platter," so that was nice. Definitely get this. 5. Doro tibs (15.00): The two "tibs" came in their own separate bowls, instead of on a family-style platter, which I was surprised by. It comes with a spoon, so you spoon it onto your own individual plate, where you can eat it with injera. I guess it's neater this way. It was good, but didn't stand out too much.  6. Lega tibs (15.00): This was very good! 7. Bonus: They gave us a free "experimental" chicken tibs entree! It tasted a lot like the Doro tibs to me, but we all enjoyed it!  Sadly we had to leave before the live music started at 9 PM. We walked out as the band was setting up, and they looked like they would be a lot of fun. The restaurant took a picture of us and put it on their Facebook, which was neat! We'll be back for sure!

m-_pnRtoqOxw-zOtDADckQ.review_text: Had the veggie sampler, which was standard yummy, not mind blowing Ethiopian great.  The injera was OK.  They didn't have honey wine the night I was there, maybe they do other times.  The lounge atmosphere and jazz that started later on in the meal is what saved it from 3 to 4 stars.  Nice wait staff too.

nZ0oPk7vc7VlLlfkK-viqg.review_text: It took a place like Sheba Lounge to inspire my first Yelp.  If you've never tried Ethiopian food before, this is the place to get indoctrinated.  Spicy curries eaten with spongy bread (no forks, knives or spoons), matched with a crisp Viogner, funky live music (electric violin in our case) and friendly, sincere service.  Ridiculous collard greens.

QbetpsWhg_WEvMwx6RkMJA.review_text: Love love LOVE this place!! Food is great, the servers are very nice (especially the main lady), decor is comfy, and love the live music! Its become a way-too-frequent friday/saturday dinner haunt.  Veggie food review: Veg sambusas are the best! The okra appetizer dish is worth trying too. We always get the veg platter and order for extra mesir-wat. I personally also love the dressing on the salad (that comes with the platter).  Service and food has been consistently great everytime I've gone over the past many months. Our last dinner, a group of 12 of us headed there for a birthday dinner on V-day, expecting a long wait since we couldn't make a reservation beforehand. Put in our name and were told to check back in 45 minutes, we decided to hang around right outside anyway, and we had a table in less than half an hour! Inspite of the busy-ness and our huge group, everything was perfect, as usual.

GHZdMggvuYk1fsVWcyy0JQ.review_text: Very cute restaurant with flavorful food and good drinks.   Their version of a Dark and Stormy was excellent. The ginger flavors were very refreshing. The Pineapple Har Har my friend ordered was a little too sweet for my taste (and my signature drink is a Midori Sour) so unless you like syrupy sweet drinks, maybe you should try something else.  I think the Har Har needed a balance to the sweetness, like maybe some crushed basil.  For food, we tried the crab samusas, boneless chicken, and collard greens. However, don't make the mistake we did, which was to ask that the chicken be spicy. It was very, very spicy. Good, but after a few bites, my mouth was on fire.  The servers are friendly but a little slow with refilling water (which is especially important when you're eating spicy food).  The seating area is fairly small so unless you're eating early, it's not a good place for a group larger than four.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: Remember the scene from "Along Came Polly" when Ben Stiller ate spicy Moroccan food that sent him running to the turd aquarium? SH*T, I DO... My first experience with Ethiopian food several years ago had me hugging the porcelain throne from both ends for hours. Can we say, skiiiiidmarks? Sorry, TMI. Needless to say, I shied away from Ethiopian food, Eritrean food, and anything of the like. Bubble guts are so not sexy...but Sheba Piano Lounge IS. Opening in 2006 and with less than 300 reviews, Sheba Piano Lounge is probably one of the most undervisited places in San Francisco. Part bar, part restaurant, and part lounge, Sheba Piano Lounge is a perfect place to bring a date. The Mr. choose very well. Good boy. Do note that there are only about 20-25 seats in the dining room (outdoor patio seating available). Also, the tables are very very close together so it's hard to hold a conversation without speaking over the people next to you. Reservations are recommended. For those not familiar with Ethiopian cuisine, it's filled with bold, fragrant, and fiery spices. Most of the dishes are stew-like and are served over Injera, spongy bread made out of teff (high in protein and dietary fiber). Everything is meant to be eaten with your hands. Pull apart a piece of Injera to wrap up a small piece of meat or veggie and ENJOY! The friendly and knowledgeable staff is more than happy to make food recommendations and teach you how-to eat the Ethiopian dishes.   I started with the Makeda Martini ($9) which was made with Hendricks, fresh cucumber and white grape juice. If you're a gin gal like myself, this is a must order for some sweet flirty giggles (I had two). For our app, we went with the Crab Sambussa ($8) which is like an Ethiopian egg roll. yelp.com/biz_photos/TDG3… The hefty cigars were very crunchy and generously filled with sweet tender crab meat and carrots and apples for an added crunch. As our entree, the Lega Tibs ($15) and Beg Alecha ($15.50) arrived atop Injera bread with salad (extra Injera bread was served on the side). yelp.com/biz_photos/TDG3… The Lega Tibs were tender beef strips simmered in Berbere sauce with a touch of purified butter for a layer of richness. The combo of chili peppers, garlic, ginger, basil, korarima (ginger family) and black pepper created a robust and fiery explosion in my mouth. Equally as good was the Beg Alecha, braised lamb in a green pepper and herb sauce with rosemary for a touch of earthiness. With each Injera stuffed morsel, make sure to include a salad leaf dressed with the tangy vinaigrette which offset the sourness of the bread perfectly.   Our deliciously fiery dinner at Sheba definitely set the tone for the rest of the night. There were NO bubble guts so you know what that meant...SEXY TIME! (^ _~) OTHER NOTES: *Most popular dishes are the Sambussa, Vegetarian Sampler, Wat and Tibs. *Level of spiciness can't be requested as the spice blends are already made. *Live jazz music starts at 9 PM. *Garage parking available at Club One garage several doors away for $3 the first hour and $1 for each additional hour. Closes at 2 AM.

McUAy628C6jpEyZecmAMGw.review_text: I feel like this place could have been better but the lady that came up to us when we walked in had an attitude. The live music was nice, but one of the Asian piano players was totally drunk and pretty much falling all over himself and all his band members. So besides the band having disagreements with who or what to play the décor is pleasant. I do think that the table layout is slightly awkward. Also, beware of the one-drink minimum before going in. I didn't see a sign on the door outside or anywhere on the menu so be prepared to be told frankly that you have to buy at least one drink or probably risk being told to leave. The kitchen was closed by the time I arrived so I couldn't try the food to be able to share my thoughts about that.

Rqg9Rf5ybblqBZ0p5iPn7g.review_text: Happy Birthday, Anne Marie B.!  We celebrated Anne Marie's 25th in style, in cushy leather couches by the fireplace with live jazz.  The food was great, but it was kind of awkward eating on couches off of basically coffee tables...and trying to share with twelve other people at the same time.  But, we're all friends here, just grab a towel bread (sorry, this is what we called them...) and have at it!  The music was super relaxing, at one point they played/sang My Girl and we all started swaying and singing along :-)

LtPr3ci_my5rfbw8y_4yBA.review_text: went tonight with a party of two.  pros:  food was not as spicy as other places, the limited menu was very tasty.  Got two dishes off the veggie section and it was tasty, yum! good appetizer as well.  there is a long list of creative cocktails.  owner came around to thank us for eating here.  blues or jazz piano 4 piece band adds to the ambiance.  Beautiful decor with exotic colors, drapes that looks a lot more expensive than the actual price tag. in my humble opinion, really deserves more traffic than what it's getting on a sunday night, would recommend definitely.

wDBhko083sYILyEeF-XMRQ.review_text: This is the perfect place - it really is.  Great Food - check Amazing live music - check Perfect atmosphere/ambience/decor - check Friendly/Attentive service - check Good location - check Timings - check (food served till 11 in the nite and the place is open till 2)  I love the overall experience of this place - I find something new to eat everytime I go, like the spicy fries or the veggie sambussa or the okra preparation with the most amazing crisps!  The main course is the standard misir wot + kik alicha preparation with fresh injera and I just love it.  The best part of course is the relaxed atmosphere and the chance to soak in some nice live music played by the very talented musicians - I live in Mountain View, but I have been here about 4 times in the past year, and look forward to going here every time we make a plan to hang out in the city.

iQvk53lSug_7ndGw-kmM6w.review_text: Very delicious food, and enjoyable music. Service was good and staff friendly. Highly recommend.

E-VcjSaqij21LkDTz8dE-g.review_text: This is authentic Ethiopian cuisine at it's best. As an Ethiopian I know my food. This is the food I grew up with. All of the spices are imported directly from Ethiopia. The decor is warm, intimate and inviting.  They have a reproduction of Lalibela, a cozy fireplace and live jazz every night with no cover.   It is the perfect date spot.  The service is outstanding and the drinks are amazing. The owners have taken classic cocktails and put an Ethiopian twist on them.   My favorite items are: all of the Ethiopian food, the pomegranate meatballs and the samosas.  They have a great wine, scotch and whisky list. My friends' love the Sheba burger.  It is owned by two sisters Net & Israel. They have created a setting that makes you feel welcome and satisfied.  I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! I TELL EVERYONE I KNOW ABOUT THIS PLACE!!!!

bK7K4HkqatCj7zKHvYIH5A.review_text: Yumyumyum!! The food here is goooooood. Went last night with five people total so I got to try a lot of different stuff. We got the vegetarian sampler, the chicken (Doro Tibs I think), one of the beef dishes (TIbs Wat - didn't try it - I don't eat beef). the lentil samboosas, the spinach dip and the baklava. OMG the food is soooo good. My favorites were the Gomen - the collard greens veggie dish. It's usually my favorite and it was spiced perfectly. I also really liked the spinach dip and that surprised me. It's definitely not what I was expecting, but it has a little bit of a kick to it and it is way better than any of that americanized cream cheese spinach mess. The other highlight (not that there were any lowlights on the food front) was the baklava. Holy eff man. Served slightly warm and flavor was perfect.   So the food was totally five stars. The seating was not perfect though. We were seated at a low table with arm chairs around which made for a slightly awkward eating experience. I think we all would have preferred to sit at an actual table. Especially since two of us were wearing shorter dresses and, well it took some work and fancy napkin placement to not flash my dining companions. So that was a minor setback but the food was so good that it almost didn't matter.

xvAlmbkz6vjuhBsmFThlFg.review_text: Very good authentic ethiopian food. Ambiance is great especially when the piano player is there at night. I like the doro tibs (sautéed chicken), veggie platter (especially the aliche!), and lentil sambussa.

hcGgZ4PbKcM3K1clw7tEGA.review_text: Has anyone been a to Berkeley or East Bay Ethiopian food place? Like an actual Ethiopian place?  Because I've been to at least three places which were more authentic, cheaper and had what would compute as GOLIATH portions compared to Sheba. Restaurants that actually serve milk and honey.  Sheba is basically the equivalent of that fancy McDonalds in New York... knock off food and great atmo. However there is one big difference, unlike Mickey D's Sheba is crazy expensive.  My half of the bill was 14 bucks and seeing as I had 3 small meatballs and about 1/4 of the less than half of a fistful size of meat that made up the dish I'd say I was robbed. Had I not been on a date I probably would have announced WTF?  The waiter was polite and nice, and the food was tasty, but for what we received 30+ dollars was not worth it at all. The music was nice, the lounge comfortable... but seriously guys... it's a restaurant, you can't just jack up your food prices and lower your portion size to pay for the money you lose on atmosphere.   So if you're just in it for the atmo and drinks, I guess it's not a bad place to meet.

kRbwfbRmuan0Y_JfOwtwjQ.review_text: This place was awesome!  DELICIOUS food!  Loved the chicken, veggie sampler, and the beef.  Definitely recommend.

7cL3Bo3SzA85yjKPtkimqA.review_text: I took my mom here for her first Ethiopian food experience.  I'd never been to this location before, so I really hoped it would back up all of the hype I had been creating around this delicious cuisine.  Unfortunately, it did not.  The sweet potato fries were delicious (how can you go wrong?!) and the ketchup for dipping had an extra kick to it.  The vegetarian sampler was okay, but not as flavorful or memorable as other places I've visited.  The real bummer was that the service was non-existent.  Our waitress was barely around and probably only uttered a handful of words.  I had to hunt her down in order to get our check (the restaurant was not busy) and when I paid and thanked her, she did not reciprocate the gratitude.  Very bizarre.  We won't be coming back.  :(

Pf79R-WRZnk6l0lEq8unhQ.review_text: I expected something a little more exotic. It's a regular restaurant that happens to serve food on top of a spongy bread in a big plate. I left full and satisfied but after a while, all the flavors started to blend in together.  The band was setting up while we were eating and toward the end of our meal, it seemed like our conversations were intruding on their space so we left. It doesn't seem like an appropriate place to linger and catch up with friends.

AjAL1T3oK5kxlDoMT2yvHQ.review_text: Ok, so the decor is not great, the crowd is not trendy and the waitresses not cute.  But Sheba Lounge is a nice place to cozy up by the fireplace on a cold night.  I think the best feature of this place is the great lounge music that attracts a slightly older, more subdued crowd (you'll like it if this is your thing) .... When I do not feel like making an effort to look cute for drinks and appetizers, and I just want to listen to kick-back loungy music -- I know of a place to go: Sheba Lounge!  And oh, parking is super easy - park by Safeway, and cross the street!

-Ln2zi3V-GknO2RBAAsT-g.review_text: So I went back, as I had planned, to give Sheba a second try by ordering some of the Ethiopian food.  Well I happy to say that the Tibs Wat was AWESOME, and I had no complaints whatsoever.  It was a friday night, the place was packed, a nice atmosphere, all kinds of different people in there.  The waitress discovered that I was the guy who wrote the review on the WTF Cheeseplate (see my previous review) and she assured me it was an honest mistake by a junior food prepper.  They were very nice, and I am glad I went back.  I will be back again!!!

A0uUf3hf22H0hR3iFq9TWA.review_text: Love this place! A San Francisco favorite for relaxing over classy drinks, delightful music, and amazing Ethiopian food. Good service, intimate atmosphere.

4qsVIa8wP0EDk86VogIs1Q.review_text: This is brunch review: Not to-die-for by any stretch, a decent egg combo with spinach, bell peppers, and mushrooms was served with spicy fried potato squares and sliced fruit. Really just mediocre. Both K and M opted for spicier renditions that included Ethiopian spices that I did not try. The true gem of the restaurant was its Sunday-morning piano player. Over Mimosas and Bloody Marys, breakfast was more than thoroughly enjoyed to Gary's performance of Cole Porter and Gershwin standards performed with tremendous feeling and grace. There is a place I will definitely be looking forward to returning to - if only for the piano music!

eUmVXP9UnoWtz9NSBwY4jA.review_text: Sing us a song, you're the piano man! Sing us a song tonight...  Ok, I'll spare you the rest.  What you need to know is there's a cool piano lounge mere blocks from the Fillmore! We stopped in before the Travis concert for a couple of drinks and some food and got a show to accompany our meal. And the folks at Sheba do know how to put on a show...if you thought the Mint had some ringers, wait until you check out the gang that hangs out here (with their own sheet music!)  The food was pretty tasty - I love eating with my hands!  And my cucumber cosmo was icy and oh so cucumbery.  Service was super friendly but painfully slow...we had to track down our waitress to order coffee and to pay the bill, but I won't hesitate to return to Sheba Lounge.  Who knows, next time I might even get up and sing.   Just kidding, I wouldn't force that on anyone.

fSvOdnryI9FPJ2ylcsE2ig.review_text: I used to think the food was great here, but not only has the food quality gone down, the service is TERRIBLE. I've never experienced such slow service. The new waitress didn't seem to know what she was doing. It took forever to get anyone's attention and was as difficult to get water refilled. And, the check took 15 or so minutes to finally get processed.  I know people like coming for the bar and piano lounge. I guess if you are on a slow date, it's fine...but if you are hungry or have time constraints don't go here.  And, worse, the food was sub-par. Some of our veggie platter was cold. The chicken was ok, but wasn't as flavorful as other Ethiopian restaurants in the city.

H6jTNC6LUUZ8bqg9Jzq0aw.review_text: As comfortable as a living room, the food was delicious and plentiful.  I ate at the bar with my husband, listened to live music that was great, but not deafening, and enjoyed a delicious meal. It was a great value. We had a mix of vegetarian dishes and the beef tibs. I understand that they so authentic that they import their spices from Ethiopia.

T10OVryXjBITJ1w_7_hsSw.review_text: Good food. Doesn't look like a lot but pretty filling. Can always get more of the bread stuff if needed.   5 of us had a Vegetarian Sampler, Beef Sirloin, and a beef tartar. sirloin was really good. a bit too much tartar. In vege sampler, the vege with potato stuff was good, and so were the lentils.  The Ethiopian beer was also good. wouldn't recommend you get the cocktails to go with the food. My friends who got it didn't think it went well with the food.  As the live musicians came on, it got more difficult to have conversation, and as it got later, it was harder to get our waitress, but overall it was good. Gets pretty packed later on. Good thing we got there around 7ish on a Friday night.

Sj-pHb0fy66m58D-Uu6RQA.review_text: Great vibe, good service, delicious Ethiopian food. I wasn't hungry and was splitting with someone, but ended up gobbling up out my food, it was so good. Got the vegetarian platter, which came with 6 or so rolls of Ethiopian bread. I'll definitely be back soon!

5OtRHM6zJYPMmzaMZo1-HQ.review_text: This place worked beautifully for a casual birthday celebration.  4 1/2 stars.  The Oracle convention snarled up downtown traffic, so the Fillmore area seemed like a good meeting place.  It's well lit, nearby parking, good transit, lots of food options.  I wanted Ethiopian food (injera!!) and a relaxed place to gather, so I reserved a table at Sheba Piano Lounge.  We were the first ones there at 6:30, so we ordered drinks and appetizers.   The decor is charming and relaxing, with textured walls in saturated colors.  Another reviewer called it "friendly and seductive", which is a pretty good way to describe it.  We monopolized the low-slung comfortable chairs in the lounge area near the fireplace while we waited for the rest of our group to arrive, .    Drinks arrived quickly and were extremely tasty.  The appetizers took way longer than they should have--20 to 25 minutes.  But we really liked the meatballs and spicy fries once they arrived.   Once everyone had arrived, we moved to a table to eat more comfortably.   Only caveat is that it was too dark to see our menus but my SO always has a flashlight with him!  We shared a family-style meal, passing all the dishes around.  Food was plentiful, tasty, and (because we asked for it) medium spicy.  Plenty of attention from the waiter, but not too much.  Everyone was full, full, full at the end, even my SO with the hollow leg.    The owner stopped by to check on our meal.  After she heard that it was my birthday, I was surprised with some lovely cake to share and several renditions of Happy Birthday (including one from the band).  Awww!  I was really touched!!  Oh, yes, we loved the reggae-jazz band with steel drum.  Dinner for 6 with 2 appetizers, plus some wine, cocktails and drinks came to about $160 (including tax & tip).  A bit of a splurge for us, but well worth it.    Cons: Appetizers took long time to come; too dark to read menu. Pros: EVERYTHING ELSE!    Very happy!  I would love to come back!

Km2QgGIJZjf-AwNtgYQ_YQ.review_text: Before I proceed, this review is about a bartender at Sheba and does not reflect on the quality of food and/or the rest of the staff there (all of which has been quite good)!  TL;DR version: One of the bartenders (who has apparently has worked there for 4 years) is an overly-cocky, down-right unprofessional douchebag, who proceeded to mime masturbating and sucking a cock while mixing drinks with around 10-12 customers sitting right in front of him at the bar!  It was around 7:30PM on a saturday evening, and it was hard to get a table. So we decided to sit at the bar. We ordered drinks and food and were having a nice conversation, when I notice the bartender making drinks in an unusual manner. While shaking two drinks, the bartender decides to use them as props for his mime act in which he was masturbating and sucking a cock!  And it was a very open and obvious gesture, which he then proceeded to share with the other bartender, and then with the two waitresses by the kitchen window, picking up dishes to serve. Oh... and there were close to 10 people sitting at the bar and a few folks waiting behind them to order drinks as well.  I should have gotten up and left at that very point. But I decided to ignore it, which in retrospect was a very poor decision. I should have brought it to the attention of the owner/hostess, who happened to be busy at that time. But the rest of the staff, including the other bartender were quite aware of the antics of their colleague.  Our appetizers were brought out, and my friend asked for some silverware... to serve the sauce. Instead we were greeted with "This is finger food. You eat it with your hands", in a downright condescending tone. Yet again, I chose to remain silent and not try to spoil the mood.  Finally, when the food came, the same bartender decided to serve a couple of spoons of the Tega Wat on my plate. I politely said that I could serve myself, and that he didn't need to do so. He mentioned that it was his job to serve the food, at least 2 spoonfuls of it, otherwise he would get into trouble with the owner/hostess. I just let him serve me and proceed to start eating.  But even before I could have the first bite, I hear the voice of our good ol' cocky bartender directed at me saying "I don't come down to your place of work and tell you how to do your job. Don't be telling me how to do mine!"  At this point, I was furious. I should have thrown the food and drink in his face! I should have created a scene right there to call him out on his bullshit! But more civil minds prevailed and I told him that I wasn't telling him how to do his job. Rather I was telling him how I like to eat my food that I was paying for! We got our food to go, and obviously I left no tip for the service. I tried to find the hostess to report the issue, but couldn't see her around. So I decided to write my feedback on the check itself.  BOTTOM-LINE: I AM NEVER GOING BACK TO SHEBA PIANO LOUNGE AGAIN!

UYCatc8-6ffTmG-BVCnqIg.review_text: What a hidden gem in Fillmore district.  This is an interesting place that plays LIVE Jazz music and serves Ethiopian food. I found it to be very classy and yet very casual and relaxing. Jazz music just sets the mood and ambiance. The crowd tends to be on mature side and food served is pretty tasty. I had the Veggie sampler and it was really good. Their Pinot is amazing. It is very mouthful, lush and full bodied wine. Espresso Martini is pretty good too. Overall, this is a great place to unwind by listening to some amazing live Jazz and eating delicious Ethiopian food.

KT4ooyYDRPYZ1OXDvHIncw.review_text: Look, I love this lounge. The food and drinks are great but here's what I want to make known.  My friend and I were sitting at the bar enjoying some drinks, when we witness the owner/manager verbally abusing the poor bartender girl. It was very disturbing because she did it right in front of the customers. She didn't just do it once. But in the short time we were there, about 40 min, she did it repeatedly. I was honestly surprised the bartender girl was not in tears or didn't walk out. I personally thought the drinks she, the bartender girl, Karina made us were delicious and just right, (and we are experienced SF cocktail drinkers and picky!) and she had a great personality and was extremely attentive to us the whole time we were there! 6 STARS FOR KARINA!  All I want is for this abuse and humiliation of her employee to STOP! NOW!  Or I will be taking further action to make sure she, the Ethiopian woman owner is investigated more thoroughly.  Otherwise, Jazz music, ambiance everything else, 5 stars. But treat your employees with some respect, humanity and compassion. and let them know when they are doing things GOOD and RIGHT. Karina is a gem to put up with you and her service and drinks were excellent! And for goodness sakes, DO NOT correct employees in front of the customers! Not only does it make you the owner look miserable, sloppy and unprofessional, It messes up everyone's vibe.

PhQ09uf1hzidelWoQ71gWA.review_text: RECOMMENDATION:  Vegetarian Sampler (?)- Use your hands! Pretty neat. I thought it was pretty good since I've never really tried it. Foods full of spice making it very tasty. The type of meat you choose will be placed in the middle. It does get greasy though.    For my very first time trying out Ethiopia food, it's not that bad here.
