rrYkyfKDnnhmXT6arNDNmw.review_text: very pleasant setting!  dim lights, piano player, very relaxing.  we got an appetizer... something lentils?  it was like a samosa... very, very good.  i got the riesling which was delicious (had a taste of the honey wine too, which tastes like honey and is quite good, though sweet) and boyfriend got the windmer on tap.  he got the lamb and i got the veggie platter.  it was pretty good, my first time having ethiopian food.  you pick up the food with this spongy crepe-like bread.  anyway, we had a very nice evening :) though i don't think ethiopian food is our thing, it's a very nice setting to dine or have a few drinks with a date or a close friend or two!

9NPiCqusdnh8tqW2Can2Zg.review_text: Catfish was great.  Don't bother with the fries, definitely didn't taste or look freshly made, and that is pretty darn easy.  I don't need to go again though, unless it is raining and I'm in the hood.  I'm gluten free, which they understood, and my meal was still served on top of injera.  Duh?  Service was scattered.   If you like synthesized Jazz and, well, you choose...

cEELZ8cZdi7oQe-A3eRKcQ.review_text: I went here on a Friday after 8pm with a group of 15, and they were able to reserve us a table.  The waiter/staff were super nice and attentive. I've tried Ethiopian food before, and I didn't like it; however, the food here was pretty good. Our party bought family style, so we got to try mostly everything. I don't remember the names for the best dishes, but I'm sure you'll be satisfied if you chose any random dish.  I ended up staying with a friend after our group left. This place is pretty good if you have a small group, or if you're going one on one. There was a live jazz band, which was fun to watch. We spoke to the bartender, and he said Wednesday's and Sunday's are pretty good if you're looking for a more mellow atmosphere. On Friday's and Saturdays, it can get a little bit more crowded. There were a lot of people there, but I was able to sit at different spots with my friend.  Overall I had a good experience, and I'd go here again.

cbvZS8riAjrgTg9b34o39A.review_text: This too was my first foray into Ethiopian food!  This place was recommended by my Ethiopian taxi driver.  I was more than a little skeptical though based on his earlier recommendation of Mamacitas...AND before you get all bent out of shape, I like Mamacitas enough but I just think it's an overrated Marina spot, and I am NOT a Marina kind of girl.    Live music was really really good.  Ambiance was great with low lighting.  Owner was helpful, knowing that we'd never tried this type of food.  As mentioned in another review, they actually encourage you not to sit at a table...we sat at a table anyway...go figure!  Drinks/food were moderately priced.  Even without knowledge about the food, it was easy to pick out things that sounded yummy (and were).  Appetizer prices were a steal and highly recommended.    Food was good - slightly spicy (but not spicy enough for me!) But, 2 bad things that happened:  (1) my fiance found some kind of "rock" in one of the appetizers...still not quite sure what that was...and we never ended up bringing it the server's attention. (2) For entrees ordered a meat dish + veggie combo plate.  Server didn't write it down.  They only put in the order for the beef.  My sister is a vegetarian.  So, we had wait for veggie combo plate to be made, which was kinda annoying.  Besides these 2 honest mistakes, I will definitely be back.  The spongy bread is adddddicting.

uU7GIgzs4-5Dtp9Vuymb3A.review_text: Came across this place while waiting for Brian McKnight. It was a nice joint and the drinks were really good. I had something that tasted like a cucumber crush, it was the right alcohol content :-).  Wonder how the crowd is at night.

ZBltO4yUbn333jh0pWoy3Q.review_text: Wonderful Food. Wonderful Atmosphere. Wonderful Service!

kfKPWb2KniBZl9W9mIAr4Q.review_text: There once was a cuisine of heaven,  Whose dishes were scooped with bread unleavened -  Friends with wine, served family style,  With food originating from the Blue Nile...  Come to Sheba! Turn it up to eleven.   While the food here was outstanding, I had to give it three stars for the terrible service. I give the Pomegranate Meatballs FIVE stars and the TERRIBLE lack of kindness a 1. So that evens out to 3.   ............and I quote, while asking the waitress for water...."I'll see what I can do, but I cant promise anything"---- Hmmmm.   LENTILS 4 EVA!

GEKkcZHWMlA5DKkN_5vSnA.review_text: I had the urge to try some Ethiopian food and couldn't have asked for a more relaxing night! Sheba seems well suited as an intimate dinner venue. Don't bother if you're looking for a quick bite to eat, because the food does take some time to come out. However, if you've got great company it's worth the wait.   We had a party of six friends and started off with the sambussas (sirloin steak and spicy lentil) as our appetizers. These were my favorites with the tangy dipping sauce. We pretty much devoured these small plates collectively in less than 5 minutes.   I ordered some honey wine just to try, and it's definitely strong and sweet!  My friend and I split the vegetarian sampler. Netsanet (the executive chef) assisted with bringing out the food to us, so it was impressive to see the woman behind this Fillmore gem.   My only criticism: the restaurant was understaffed that night, because we had only one waitress who also worked the bar. Otherwise, you can't go wrong with the live jazz music (we had a pianist) and the fireplace. Great place to unwind at the end of a long day.

msHp-UVjTCeBzRyRtqGjBQ.review_text: I cannot WAIT to be back in San Francisco so I can munch on many an injera and just chill here listening to good jazz!  I discovered this place after getting out of Yoshi's one night (which closes pretty early for a jazz joint).  Luckily for me, I was in for one hell of a wonderful surprise.  While I absolutely loved the music at yoshi's, the food left a lot to be desire and that's where Sheba's comes in.  The food and service here is phenomenal and blows many jazz venues out of the water for that alone.

1Y0gtTwmX6ETormKrO5xTg.review_text: my boyfriend and I came across this place on a wednesday night and we are now eager to be regulars.  the atmosphere is cozy and inviting.  the food is good and the drinks, inexpensive.  what really sells it is the music.  we spent the whole night sitting by the fireplace listening to wonderful jazz.  I cannot believe that in the two years that I have been in sf, this was the first time that I had ventured there.  I will be back on a weekly basis for sure.  places like these are rare and priceless.

vn4R-226ohQK8-yleO1xuQ.review_text: The Jazz here was amazing- too bad no one else was there to listen to it. I loved the food, the service was a little scattered but not too bad.

iLJHT_hnJFQ96BbRWtXyvA.review_text: Ate here loved it. ambiance is great, and free live music doesnt hurt either. anytime u can eat on a couch with a fireplace in front of u is a plus. the veggie sampler is awesome... great spot for a date or an important event, or just wanting to be out on the town. oh btw u eat with your hands... awesome!

-fZXqbzurkqTV48lovxFpw.review_text: I went for my first time last night. The food was delicious and the portions were perfect. The music was very good. I will return soon.

nM0mhuJdTps_9fuJ6RTQ7g.review_text: This place is amazing. It was so much fun from the moment we entered. They had live music and the atmosphere was great, we only had some drinks with some friends since we weren't hungry, but we will definitely come back and try the food next time!

9kte4taluSCDvNLJCnoJ4w.review_text: Not impressed at all by this place. The service was really bad. I had to flag the waiter down every time I needed something, and this would happen after not being checked on for 20+minutes. Unacceptable.   You can always tell if a place is good by the type of host ethnicity that frequents the place. For instance, if you see a lot of Indians at an Indian restaurant then you know its good. Know what I mean?   The chicken dish was not good at all. Plus, my bread was soggy!? Haha jk I know its suppose to be and it was decent. The beef and salad were pretty tasty though.   I wanted a more ethnic vibe, but that is my fault for expecting an ethnic vibe at a "Piano Lounge." The search continues for a true Ethiopian experience.

lK_32lYJ-p_fjc01G-DPLw.review_text: Hung out here during the Fillmore Jazz festival. The bartenders are friendly, and the service is good. Lovely to be somewhere with free live jazz.

URvZ0BkUDZABI6wgCAo5dA.review_text: *comfy couches for lounging and eating *a fireplace *excellent ethiopian, veggie friendly! *free live jazz most nights *charming, family owned *super cozy, relaxing space to spend an evening  I love this place. It's definitely one of my go-to spots in the neighborhood, and great for a low key night, a date, or a group gathering. If you call ahead to reserve the couch area, it's like a living room, but with full service drinks and Ethiopian food.

GzORTCRGhmQ0IBXq6UHpOw.review_text: This is an awesome place with great ambiance.  They normally have some sort of live music, and I love sitting my the fireplace.  Their fish is a pretty good deal, and their home made salad dressing is delicious.   Main downside is that while their drinks are fairly priced, they seem to be watered down.  And their wine selection is limited.

DSk7K0soSYU9VWEZl0xBpQ.review_text: This was my first time having Ethiopian food and I must say I am such a big fan. The place is small, so at times it can be a tight squeeze to get by. The only complaint that I had was that they need to hire more staff for a Saturday night. But other than that, it was a great overall experience. I will come back to this place for sure!!!  I ordered the CAtfish with rosemary and by BF ordered the beef slices (i forgot what the dish was called). For an appetizer we ordered the beef sambussa and the pita chips with dip. Everything was wonderful.

iRNCdVNJyN8rLLMGWi0UtA.review_text: Waiting for a concert at the Fillmore (which has a no in/out policy)-- dropped in here!  I wish we hadn't already eaten because I love exotic food, but we went to the bar instead.  Nice, calm, great music in the background, and nice architectural details.  Would definitely suggest for a drink or two, and maybe even try the food!  Drinks were pretty reasonable, too-- and we weren't even there at happy hour (5-7).

82dCHyU-ANOgdhxUgZsUeg.review_text: I had something to do at 7:00PM in Japantown so my friends and I made our way here at 5:30PM for some food/drinks. I wanted to hear someone playing the piano while enjoying a cocktail, which was the compelling reason we came here but I'm not sure why I was expecting someone to be playing piano around opening time. I think the live music comes on around 7:00PM. So, we basically just ate and drank in an Ethiopian restaurant without any music making the decision to go here pointless. With this said, I would not recommend coming here around opening time unless you really just want some Ethiopian food. This is a nice place to check out and listen to live music if you're on a bar hopping mission around Fillmore St. Don't be like me and think there will be live music from opening to close.

s16-BUo-orUsELvMu5ocKg.review_text: I remember when Rasselas and Sheba were two separate lounges. Now Rasselas is closed and the kitchen staff has moved to Sheba. Thankfully, the vibe, music and cuisine haven't changed much during the transition. Got the vegetarian combo and tibs wot. Both were delicious and well-cooked. The injera was among the better ones I've had--sour, firm without being too soggy. Friendly service topped off a great night.

MhU43gZSyKr4--82dq6RSg.review_text: I've had good Ethiopian food in some places like Atlanta, Denver and Oakland Claremont district's own Messob. This place is really good, a lot better than the ones I have had before.   We went in a group of 4; Atmosphere is more like a lounge, a date place, but the food is excellent. We ordered drinks that I haven't spotted elsewhere like this concoction called the Abyssinian something that had either vodka or gin and ginger beer and something else that had champagne. The drinks were really good.  For food we ordered the veggies sampler, the lentils and collard greens were really excellent. We also shared the chicken tibs and the beef doro wat which I must say was really outstanding!! We shared a single chocolate cake mousse type  dessert which was decent. Total bill was around $100 with 5 drinks and dinner for 4 so its quite decently priced for San Francisco.

9G71FMxVIDTpALU58x-FJg.review_text: I had never had Ethiopian food before coming to this place and didn't know what to expect.  Needless to say, I was pleasantly surprised.  The atmosphere is pretty chill.  Big lounge chairs and live music with wide low-rise coffee tables for the food.  It reminds me of a study room almost, except with a little bit of jazzy music.  A great place for a conversation.  The food was delicious.  There's a certain novelty to the cuisine-- it's unlike anything else I've had-- and frankly, it's pretty tasty.  It's great for a group of 3-4 people because you can get different dishes and it's served on a communal platter.  I recommend getting one veggie dish... the meat dishes are awesome, but I was surprised to find that I actually like the vegetables too and they mesh well with the other flavors.  Enjoy!

QocP49nZ7Fo-4Rp_QxPuDQ.review_text: I choose this place bc on a lateish (9pm), rainy, and crowded SF evening, bc of the ease of parking in the Fillmore (parking garage and Safeway parking lot). Also, it has a bar and had nice Yelp ratings.  Inside is a lovely piano bar, with live music. They have champagne cocktails, it's dark and cozy, and the food was flavorful. It was very lovely for an impromtu dinner. I'll be back to sit in the lounge next time!

NKKW2bUyFUGy15-Fvc0KJw.review_text: Greeted by a friendly woman in Ethiopian attire. Gave us a heads up, band would be starting soon and it may get loud, gave other seating options.  Bar seating was great! Live Music......good food.......friendly people......dim lighting.....  After we ate half of our meal, bartender said, "Oh I guess I should' have told you what that was on the Vegetarian Sampler plate?" Lucky for him, we knew, and didn't mind eating with our hands!   :-)

FNC0miRIn6WjiVrrNlmJ_A.review_text: I've been here twice now, once for a date and another time with friends. This is a wonderfully low-key lounge. Perfect lighting, live music, pleasant atmosphere, attentive and polite wait staff and unexpected bar treats. I should spend my night's out around Filmore more often and Sheba would be a great place to be.

qiLQLD-mfbL7W83lOM3uVg.review_text: Stopped by here on a weekday evening. The Ethiopian food served here is good but very expensive.  You should come here for the ambiance; by that I mean the comfortable sofas (there are no dining tables next to the sofas), the fireplace, the low lights and the decor. This is a great  place to bring a date or to have a business dinner.   You are definitely paying for a relaxing environment, food is a secondary item.

tTrT_nPMl4GvWOuXSWSJ8g.review_text: So I called ahead to see about the pianist. Nope, not tonight, but whatever, i wanted to hang out with my friends, so nothing to strain over was fine by me.  Tuesday night, not busy, seated immediately.  Bottle of Tej, nicely placed on ice for us.  We ordered absolutely delish appetizer, these lentil spring rolls basically. I think they were called samussa's? with a tangy dip.  holy crap, so good. we shared (3 chicks) 2 of the veggie samplers as well, which was way too much food, although try as we might we were unable to finish. This was the 1st time that all the dishes in an ethiopian veggie sampler were amazing.  The lentils were rich, the split peas just the right creaminess, the hummus-like spreads a perfect complement to the hotter dishes, the alicha (cabbage and carrots) actually had flavor, and the collard greens, i haven't had such good collard greens since Massawa in NYC (nothing like Massawa here).  My east bay fav is Cafe Addis, and I must say that this is on par.  Better than Axum cafe, better than Massawa.  My friend thought much better than club waziema. Although I can only vouch for vegetarian dishes. The injera is a bit thinner than some places, but i find this more enjoyable, as you can actually consume more of the dishes and less of the bread this way.

Gq73ut3Vg9reUsS5v0fOkA.review_text: Awful / rude service despite good food. Would go back for the food but paying for unpleasant service is never worth it.  Our server was a young man who refused to sit our party of 5 at a table (though several appeared empty), would not let us move a table 2 feet accommodate the seating at coffee table we were sat at, and refused to split our bill among credit cards.  We overheard another server asking him to get more bread for us and he said "What am I stretch Armstrong." Not surprisingly we didn't get bread for 10 minutes.  Kind of a bummer experience despite a tasty meal.

F8UXRG5R_TgSNJmKKQMTSA.review_text: No cover on a Friday night, it's definitely a relaxing place and the ethiopian food and drinks were very good. I would come back here again next time I'm in the area.   There was a live band when we attended, so be ready for some noise

p-rz5nElTuSyUV1Dzui6Yg.review_text: When you walk in here you are greeted with warm, rich colors and ambient lighting. You can just curl up in the comfy chairs and listen the night away.  The drinks are tasty and the atmosphere is delicious I haven't tried the food yet, but I will soon enough. I could spend so much more time there than I do.

BTdfXMuMOcKzfY7_s76chg.review_text: This place is the titties. I love their vibe. Ethiopian food? check. Fireplace? check. Non Ethiopian food? Check check.   Nice service, great food. I always sit at the lounge, heard some amazing live music and then order the veggie sampler and any of their meat dishes. Great place when craving Ethiopian and great place to take out of towners because pretty sure they don't have these types of joints in Wisconsin.

GRh1cG-w44ALvVl0CpMw1w.review_text: Great food, cozy environment (especially if you are lucky enough to get a seat by the fire), and friendly, laid-back staff.

0_dPwHJL8bysF0RSBtsZqw.review_text: Authentic.  Even the service.  I called to make reservations and they didn't have it, even after it was confirmed.  Ahhh...takes me back to my days in Africa.  Granted, it was West Africa and nowhere near Ethiopia but work with me.  So sit back and enjoy some tasty Ethiopian food.  I heard the injera is homemade and it is by far some of the best injera I've had.  DC and NYC has some good Ethiopian places but this was pretty damn good.  Add the lounge singing and piano playing of local talent (it is in the Fillmore District) and you've got yourself a long, comfortable night in Ethiopia.  Seriously, the atmosphere makes you forget you're in this regentrified neighborhood.  I recommend you sit by the fireplace and cozy up on the sofa while you eat, drink, and talk.

6kWAL8wWRAe17ARc78Ay9w.review_text: I can't add too much more than what other reviews have stated, but I can throw a few personalized tidbits based on my own experience here the other night.  First off, there was no piano player. When we asked what time he/she might be coming in, we were told that the pianist had to go to a last minute wedding (?) and wouldn't be coming in. They couldn't get anyone else.  Also, the bartender left in the middle of dinner. He straight just waked out. That left our poor waitress manning the bar and trying to serve the entire restaurant on her own - the managers didn't even help her! Sufficeth to say, it took almost half an hour to get our bill after we asked for it, and then another 15 minutes to pass it off, and then another 15 minutes to get it back again, after being told we were given the wrong bill.  The food was good (though the beef dishes were dry), and we tried almost everything on the Ethiopian side of the menu. The Lega Tibs were great, and the spicy lentils wound up being my favorite. I was not a fan of the honey wine.   Bonus for them: they brought my lovely gf a free ice cream. Even still, we skipped dessert and rocked Miyako Old Fashioned Ice Cream across the way.

iCP_Lmh7TTxDWEQd1xWbDw.review_text: The combination of jazz and ethiopian food struck me as odd at first, but this place is awesome!  The menu has not only Ethiopian food, but also Italian and American food with an Ethiopian twist. Our waitress was very helpful and made some excellent recommendations. The spicy lentil sambussa were awesome.  Probably not a great place for a large group, but definitely a good date place, especially if you like live music.

VgtcRwMPiAEeuPsayXB4kA.review_text: Great place to chill, post-Fillmore. Good tap beer...

HC1ehl5_T79__izzteqkwg.review_text: Perfect:  Authentic dishes prepared by an Ethiopian chef (I saw her) with spices imported from Ethiopia  We had the Crab sambusas, delicate pastries filled with crab carrots apple and cilantro while listening to the  Piano player who sang and told stories of his travels. Also had the Tibs wat - sautéed prime beef simmered in Berbere sauce and a touch of nit' it kibe (Ethiopian purified butter) Finally Lega tibs - sirloin tibs in white wine, sautéed in rosemary onions and jalapeño peppers were delicious.

y0lSMH1CCRduc7Am4XCvAg.review_text: I'm really tempted to give only one star.  I'm giving it two so others realize this review has been given thought (also, I don't just give one star or five stars) and because some things could have been worse (but not much).  Arrived at 8:22pm with my girlfriend.  The place was full but there was no wait.  We are seated and immediately we noticed how there is literally no room between you and anyone else in the restaurant.  No biggie, I'm not claustrophobic.  Five minutes go by and another couple is seated next to us.  They are given menus -- we still don't have ours.  Maybe we should have left right then and there.  The waitress comes by and apologizes and gives us one menu, and says she'll be right back with a second.  Another five minutes go by and a different waitress comes by and hands me a menu.  Almost immediately after, the manager/hostess comes by and asks if we're ready to order.  Obviously we ask for a little more time.  On the menu:  several tasty looking options.  I guess if all you care about is food then this might be an OK place.  Soda / Juice for $4.  Yikes.  I go for a water, and my girlfriend orders a cranberry juice.  By about 8:40pm we place our food orders, and so does the couple next to us.  Tick tock tick tock tick tock...  20 minutes pass and the couple next to us gets their appetizer dish.  Surely our food must be shortly behind it.  Another 20 minutes pass and they have finished it and await their dinner.  We still have not gotten anything, not even an explanation as to why we have not gotten our food yet.  Another 5 minutes later, the waitress comes over and says there was a mixup in the kitchen and our food should be out shortly.  I guess her definition of "shortly" was another 20 minutes.  The couple next to us (who sat down after us, and ordered after us) finally gets their meals.  "That's almost a slap in the face" I thought to myself.  5 minutes later, ours comes out.   Yes, that's right, it took us OVER AN HOUR to get two very simple plates of food -- a small plate of Yellow Peas and the Yasa Tibs.    My girlfriend decides to ask the waitress if we can get a discount because having to wait that long for food is ridiculous.  She says she'll talk to the manager and she what she can do.  The manager a few minutes later strolls by and asks "How's your food?" -- we didn't realize she was the manager.  We found out only after the fact that that was how she decided to apologize and/or deal with the poor service.    So we eat our food, which was OK but not spectacular, and are ready to pay the bill.  We ask again what they're going to do to compensate us for our time, patience, and the extremely slow service.  The waitress says that the manager has left to her other restaurant and unfortunately now there is nothing she can do except offer us some free dessert.  Wow.  We scoff at the entire ordeal in private but ask for the ice cream with fried brioche.  "Oh, sorry we don't have the fried brioche right now, but I can give you just the ice cream".  Double wow.   We politely tell her thanks, but no thanks, and we'd still like the restaurant to do something about it.  The waitress comes back and apologizes, explaining it's a small restaurant and the kitchen got really backed up, and that she took the $4 cranberry juice off the bill as a gesture of sympathy towards us having to wait 70 minutes for food.  Other thoughts:  the jazz music was run of the mill and boring, not entertaining at all, and I do appreciate jazz.  On the way out, we saw the manager and realized that she was cowardly avoiding us.    I have never had such a terrible restaurant experience in my entire life.  Sure, things could have been worse.  But the bottom line here is that, when things went bad, the restaurant EPICALLY FAILED to try and correct them.  They basically said sorry and gave us the finger.  Dirt poor service, pricey meals for mediocre serving, crowded, and cowardly are what I would use to describe this place, and I recommend you avoid it.

jjuxiwKoiz8voegbWEJVMg.review_text: Thank the good Lord for this little gem of a restaurant!!!    I can't believe that I was never exposed to Ethiopian cuisine until Valentine's Day 2009, when the bf had the awesome foresight to have us try something new together - and boy, are we glad we did.  Upon entering Sheba, we were greeted by a festively dressed server.  Since it was V-Day, she had a pink hearts theme going on, and it was really quite cute.  Typically this kind of thing is cheesy, but for some reason, it set an appropriate tone for the rest of the evening.  One note on the service here - our server was really nice and made sure our first time was enjoyable, and the owner even stopped by to chat us up.  I love when restaurants do this because it really makes you feel like they care about your dining experience.  The owner even went so far as to ask all the patrons whether they made sure they parked legally because she said she saw some cars getting ticketed outside.  What a sweet woman!  On to the meal: It being our first time dining a la Ethiopian, we asked for recommendations, and ended up ordering the pita crisps with spicy lentil dip ($5) to start [which was actually sort of lacking in flavor].  Oh, but those entrees!!!  So delicious were the Doro Tibs - boneless pieces of chicken sauteed and seasoned with some type of Ethiopian herb, Awaze sauce, hot peppers and onions (an absolute STEAL at $12.50), and the Beg Alecha - tender pieces of lamb braised slowly in green pepper, flavored with that Ethiopian herb sauce, ginger, rosemary, and a little jalapeno pepper for spice (also at a very inexpensive $12, for sheer portion size).  This place is definitely for those who like to try exotic, spicy foods, and aren't afraid to get their hands a little dirty.  I LOVE that it's heresy to eat the above listed dishes with silverware - it's SO much fun and a little bit primal.  You use the Injera, or flat sponge bread that can be likened to a sourdough tortilla, to pick up the food.  All of the dishes we tried were scrumptious and literally finger-lickin' good!!  Also, I really appreciated the portion sizes -- I'm a big eater and I was perfectly STUFFED by the end of the meal.  I would recommend this place over and over again for its great service, reasonable price points, and very sexy ambiance.  Sure, it looks a little sketch from the outside, what with the neon sign and all, but I guarantee a very pleasant surprise waiting behind Sheba's welcoming doors.

58AH_EMcw8QS-UD12JyMmg.review_text: Beautiful decor, fabulous food! Two vegetarians and two non vegetarian had a great time.

X_fVRDdE3RVuaUuSvn4IIg.review_text: I have my friends Tina and Nikki to thank for draggin' me here!  I have never really considered myself a fan of Ethiopian food until now.  OMIGOD!  The vegetarian plate was delicious.  And, the injera bread was so fresh, unlike any I'd had before.  We sat right next to the piano and got lots of attention from the resident jazz pianist and his crew.  They were hilarious!  The only downside is the service is pretty slow.  But, if you are not in a hurry, then you will have a great time here!  Try the cucumber cosmo too!

23wQqI-DYwKkIp1av55A1Q.review_text: Great place to have a drink and listen to some excellent music.  The night we were here there was a great blues band and they were rocking out.  The wine list was ok--nothing great, but I suppose that's not their speciality.  They do have a full bar, but I was in wine mode. It can be quite loud at times and difficult to hear one another if you want to have an extended conversation.  Also, it's a small place, so the seating can be tight and even a bit difficult to find. Haven't tried the food--will have to go back.

FAgNhyOKMsxl5v5T7Rsw-Q.review_text: Have you ever been to and Ethiopian jazz place?  What I mean is and Ethiopian restaurant with Jazz music in the eve.  I visited this place on a Saturday night.  We came a little early while the band was setting up and had a few drinks.  I'm glad we did because this place became packed.  That night the band played dance music, Perfect!  I'm sorry I didn't get to try any of the food but I will be back!

9wjrx1CrmxBcDiRx0fFkKA.review_text: A cozy place with dependably great food, drinks and of course great music.

SbEfc-7FqLdB2r1Mpijcxg.review_text: This review is long over due!    Let me start by saying it's not our first time having Ethiopian cuisine.  The first time was at New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar, the food here seriously ruined it for us.  The injera was super sour and i swore never to have Ethiopian food again.  After a year or so, I felt it's only right to give Ethiopian cuisine a second chance but of course at a different restaurant.  I think it was last month or so when my boyfriend and I decided to try Sheba.  We ordered the vegetarian sampler and spicy fries to snack on.  OMGosh it was so delicious!!!  The injera was not sour and the spicy lentils were so good.  We also had some salad and the dressing was fabulous.    If you're looking to try something new and don't want to be too adventurous give Sheba a try.  You won't regret it!  I will be back =)   Thanks Sheba for restoring my faith in trying new cuisine!

6qKhOPsMPpflcautJtQGqQ.review_text: I really love this place, but I can't seem to get up here more than once in a blue moon unfortunately.  The State of the Union address was on all televisions, while the few patrons in there were quietly whispering their thoughts on Obama's pep talk for the country.  The music began after the address ended, and to my surprise was not overwhelmingly loud the way most live music tends to be.  Food-wise, you really can't compare this experience to anything else.  Last night we had the spicy lentil dip and sliders, coupled with a few glasses of wine.  The dip was phenomenal enough that we requested a spice list to make an attempt at our own personal rendition at home.  I doubt that will come anywhere close, but we just really want to be able to have it on a regular basis.  As far as the sliders go ... they were unbelievable.  The last time I was able to say that about 3 small meat patties was when Trevese was still open in Los Gatos.  And Sheba's are even better.  Impeccable service, wonderful ambience and fantastic food = memorably fun date night.

-SV_ubqtzWtTu6kTDm4Xaw.review_text: Stil love the food here...just wish there was a real waitstaff or people around who gave the appearance of caring about you and your table.

8oFZEpX00zZS1Dku2aKfcQ.review_text: Went here for the first time last night just to grab some drinks and lounge/converse. GREAT atmosphere and GREAT live music. There was a blues band playing and the intimate scene made the place very cozy. We only got drinks, but the people sitting near us got Ethiopian food, and my entire crowd looked at each other with enlarged eyes saying 'We've GOT to GET THAT next time!'.  Seriously, I didn't catch the name of the band that was playing, but they rocked it and the dim lights in the place definitely set the mood.  Very excited for this find, and can't wait to go back soon!  PS- I would say good for small groups but not a very large place, so if you want seats, recommend to go in packs of groups (no larger than 6 or so)
